THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ricky Dennis Gentry, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25949
Heard May 25, 2004 - Filed March 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John Dennis Delgado and Kathrine Haggard Hudgins, both of Columbia, for appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant appeals his convictions for accessory before the fact of armed robbery and accessory before the fact of assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK), claiming the trial court was without subject matter jurisdiction to hear the accessory charges against him and claiming the trial court erred by failing to grant a directed verdict on the accessory charges.Â  We affirm.
PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND/FACTS
On March 31, 2001, Shawn Bobo was shot to death outside his home.Â  His wife, Shanna, was shot four times, but survived her injuries.Â  Appellant was indicted for murder, ABIK, armed robbery, accessory before the fact to murder, accessory before the fact to armed robbery, and accessory before the fact to ABIK.Â  Appellantâ€™s accessory charges related to the robbery and shooting of Shawn.Â  Following a trial, the jury found appellant guilty of accessory before the fact to armed robbery and accessory before the fact to ABIK.Â  He was found not guilty of the remaining charges.Â  Appellant was sentenced to thirty years imprisonment for accessory before the fact to armed robbery and to twenty years, concurrent, for accessory before the fact to ABIK.
The State presented evidence appellant and several others, including Tommie Smith (Tommie), discussed robbing the victim of cocaine.Â  One of those present, Stanley Moore (known as Rico), testified appellant said he would kill the victim and then pulled out his gun of which Tommie took possession.Â Â Â  Rico testified he, appellant, Tommie, and Michael Osbey (Osbey) all rode in the car to the victimâ€™s house.Â  Rico testified the plan, which appellant had agreed to, was for Osbey to come in and shoot everyone.Â  Appellant and Tommie talked to the victim and went inside the victimâ€™s house.Â  A few minutes later, appellant ran out the front door and motioned Osbey to come inside.Â  Appellant, Tommie, and Osbey later ran to get in the car.Â  Tommie and Osbey had the guns and appellant had a bag of cocaine.
Shanna testified she was shot four times by Tommie and Osbey.Â  She stated appellant was not in the kitchen during a struggle for the gun between Tommie and the victim.Â  She further stated she stabbed at appellant behind the recliner in the living room. 
In appellantâ€™s first statement to police, he indicated he was present when Tommie pulled a gun on the victim and when the victim and Tommie began struggling for the gun.Â  Appellant stated he was stabbed by Shanna and that, as he was running out of the front door, he saw Osbey running towards the back door.Â  In his second statement to police, appellant admitted he went to the victimâ€™s house to rob him of cocaine and that the plan was for Tommie to pull out a gun while appellant took the cocaine.Â  After leaving the house, appellant heard shots fired when he was trying to catch up with Rico.Â  He stated that when Osbey and Tommie got in the car, Osbey had the cocaine.Â  They never split up the cocaine.
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, appellant moved for a directed verdict on the accessory charges because the State had failed to prove appellant was not present when the crimes were committed.[1]Â  The trial court denied the motion because there was conflicting evidence on the presence issue.
During appellantâ€™s case, Tommie testified he initiated the plan of robbing the victim and that appellant agreed to the plan and supplied the weapons.Â  The plan was for appellant to pretend he was buying drugs.Â  Appellant was present when Tommie pulled the gun on the victim and told the victim they were going to take the drugs.Â  Tommie and the victim began to struggle for the gun and Shanna stabbed him.Â  Then, Osbey came in and started shooting.Â  Tommie testified appellant left before the shooting started.Â  However, appellant came back inside the house after Osbey had entered and grabbed the cocaine.Â  The three left the house together with over nine ounces of cocaine, worth approximately $9,000.
Appellant testified he agreed with Tommie to purchase cocaine from the victim and later agreed to rob the victim.Â  After they passed the victimâ€™s house, appellant testified he told the others that he did not want to rob the victim.Â  Appellant testified he agreed to buy the drugs as long as Tommie did not try to rob the victim.Â  Tommie assured appellant he would not, but Tommie pulled out a gun as the victim was taking out the cocaine.Â  Tommie and the victim began to struggle and appellant hid behind a couch to stay out of the way of the gun.Â  Shanna ran by him and cut him on his back.Â  Appellant ran out the front door.Â  Osbey was already getting out of the car.Â  Rico was pulling out of the driveway and appellant waved his hand in an attempt to have Rico stop.Â  By the time he got to the edge of the yard, which is near the street, appellant heard a series of shots.Â  He continued down the street and heard more shots.Â  When Osbey later entered the car, he had the cocaine.
At the close of appellantâ€™s case, appellant renewed his motion for a directed verdict.Â  The motion was denied.Â  The jury found appellant guilty of accessory before the fact of armed robbery and accessory before the fact of ABIK.
ISSUES

  I. Did the indictmentsâ€™ failure to allege the element â€œabsence from the scene of the crimeâ€ deprive the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction to hear the accessory before the fact charges?
  II. Did the trial court err by failing to direct a verdict for appellant on the charges of accessory before the fact to armed robbery and accessory before the fact to ABIK when no evidence was presented that appellant was absent from the scene of the crime?
  III. Did the trial court err by failing to direct a verdict in appellantâ€™s favor on accessory before the fact to armed robbery when the alleged subject of armed robbery was a quantity of illegal narcotics?

DISCUSSION
I.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Appellant argues the accessory before the fact indictments deprived the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction because the indictments did not allege the element â€œabsence from the scene of the crime.â€Â  Before addressing the specific facts of this case, we first address the confusion that has arisen in past jurisprudence between the sufficiency of the indictment and the subject matter jurisdiction of the trial court.
Recently, the United States Supreme Court, in United States v. Cotton, 535 U.S. 625 (2002), held that a defective indictment does not deprive a court of jurisdiction.[2]Â  The Supreme Court explained that Ex parte Bain, 121 U.S. 1 (1887), was the progenitor of the view that a defective indictment deprived a court of its jurisdiction.Â  Bain, however, is â€œthe product of an era in which [the Supreme Court]â€™s authority to review criminal convictions was greatly circumscribed.Â  At the time it was decided, a defendant could not obtain direct review of his criminal conviction in the Supreme Court.â€Â  Cotton, 535 U.S. at 629-630.Â  As a result, the Supreme Courtâ€™s desire to correct obvious constitutional violations led to a somewhat expansive notion of jurisdiction, which was more a fiction than anything else.Â  Id. at 630.
The Supreme Court further stated that Bainâ€™s elastic concept of jurisdiction is not what the term jurisdiction means today, i.e. the courtsâ€™ statutory or constitutional power to adjudicate the case.Â  Id.Â  â€œThis latter concept of subject-matter jurisdiction, because it involves a courtâ€™s power to hear a case, can never be forfeited or waived.Â  Consequently, defects in subject-matter jurisdiction require correction regardless of whether the error was raised [below].â€Â  Id.
The Supreme Court stated that its cases after Bain have held that a defective indictment does not affect the jurisdiction of the trial court to determine the case presented by the indictment.Â  The Supreme Court then overruled Bain to the extent it held a defective indictment deprives a court of jurisdiction.
Turning to South Carolina jurisprudence, we note this Court has held that subject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong, Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 526 S.E.2d 222 (2000); and that issues related to subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time.Â  Brown v. State, 343 S.C. 342, 540 S.E.2d 846 (2001).Â  The lack of subject matter jurisdiction may not be waived, even by consent of the parties, and should be taken notice of by this Court.Â  Id.Â  However, as was done by the Supreme Court in Bain, this Court broadened the meaning of jurisdiction in State v. Munn, 292 S.C. 497, 357 S.E.2d 461 (1987).Â  Prior to Munn, the rule was that any objection to the sufficiency of the indictment, i.e. that the indictment was defective, had to be made before the jury was sworn.Â  See State v. Young, 243 S.C. 187, 133 S.E.2d 210 (1963)[3] (challenge directed to the sufficiency of the indictment rather than to the jurisdiction of the Court to try the offense charged needed to be raised by a motion to quash before the jury was sworn).Â  This rule was effectively altered by the Munn decision.
In Munn, citing 41 Am. Jur. 2d Indictments and Informations, Â§ 299 (1968), we stated that defects in the indictment that are of such a fundamental character as to make the indictment wholly invalid are not subject to waiver by a defendant.Â  We concluded that, subject to certain minor exceptions, the trial court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant for an offense when there is no indictment charging him with that offense when the jury was sworn.Â  This language conflated the meaning of subject matter jurisdiction and mixed two separate questions, i.e. whether the trial court has the power to hear a case and whether the indictment is sufficient.[4]
While our broadened definition of subject matter jurisdiction occurred more recently than during the time of Bain,[5] we find the Supreme Courtâ€™s comments in Cotton instructive.Â  As noted by the Supreme Court in Cotton and the Missouri Supreme Court in State v. Parkhurst, 845 S.W.2d 31 (Mo. 1992), subject matter jurisdiction of the circuit court and the sufficiency of the indictment are two distinct concepts and the blending of these concepts serves only to confuse the issue.Â  Circuit courts obviously have subject matter jurisdiction to try criminal matters.Â  To end the confusion that was created by Munn, we now conclusively hold that if an indictment is challenged as insufficient or defective, the defendant must raise that issue before the jury is sworn and not afterwards.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-90 (2003) (â€œEvery objection to any indictment for any defect apparent on the face thereof shall be taken by demurrer or on motion to quash such indictment before the jury shall be sworn and not afterwards.â€).Â  However, a defendant may for the first time on appeal raise the issue of the trial courtâ€™s jurisdiction to try the class of case of which the defendant was convicted.[6]
As stated in State v. Faile, 43 S.C. 52, 59-60, 20 S.E. 798, 801 (1895), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (citations omitted):

  The indictment is the charge of the state against the defendant, the pleading by which he is informed of the fact, and the nature and scope of the accusation.Â  When that indictment is presented, that accusation made, that pleading filed, the accused has two courses of procedure open to him.Â  He may question the propriety of the accusation, the manner in which it has been presented, the source from which it proceeds, and have these matters promptly and properly determined; or, waiving them, he may put in issue the truth of the accusation, and demand the judgment of his peers on the merits of the charge.Â  If he omits the former, and chooses the latter, he ought not, when defeated on the latter, --when found guilty of the crime charged, --to be permitted to go back to the former, and inquire as to the manner and means by which the charge was presented.

The indictment is a notice document.Â  A challenge to the indictment on the ground of insufficiency must be made before the jury is sworn as provided by Â§ 17-19-90.Â  If the objection is timely made, the circuit court should judge the sufficiency of the indictment by determining whether (1) the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon; and (2) whether it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense that is intended to be charged.Â  State v. Wilkes, 353 S.C. 462, 578 S.E.2d 717 (2003); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003) (sufficiency of indictment).Â  In determining whether an indictment meets the sufficiency standard, the court must look at the indictment with a practical eye in view of all the surrounding circumstances.Â  State v. Adams, 277 S.C. 115, 283 S.E.2d 582 (1981).Â  Further, whether the indictment could be more definite or certain is irrelevant.Â  State v. Knuckles, 354 S.C. 626, 583 S.E.2d 51 (2003).Â  
We note that our holding today, while overruling several cases,[7] is in line with modern jurisprudence.[8]
Addressing the instant case, appellant argues the indictmentsâ€™ failure to allege the element â€œabsence from the scene of the crimeâ€ deprives the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction to hear the accessory before the fact charges.Â  Because appellant did not raise the sufficiency of the indictments before the jury was sworn, he cannot now raise this issue on appeal.Â  The issue is not preserved for our review.
II. Absence From Scene of the Crime
Appellant argues the trial court erred by failing to direct a verdict on the accessory charges when no evidence was presented that he was absent from the scene of the crime.
A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004).Â  In reviewing a motion for directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence of the evidence, not with its weight.Â  Id.Â  On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  Id.Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, the Court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Id.
Regarding the accessory before the fact to armed robbery charge, the testimony indicates appellant was present during the time Tommie pulled a gun on the victim and informed the victim they were going to take the cocaine.Â  Rico testified appellant left the victimâ€™s house with the cocaine indicating appellant assisted in completing the armed robbery.Â  Further, appellant, in his first statement to police, did not mention the cocaine and, in his second statement, he stated that he was in the car with Rico when Osbey entered the car with the cocaine.Â  Therefore, there was conflicting evidence whether appellant was present during the taking of the cocaine from the victimâ€™s possession.[9]Â  
Regarding the crime of accessory before the fact to ABIK, Rico testified appellant motioned Osbey to enter the victimâ€™s home pursuant to the plan for Osbey to come in and shoot everyone.Â  Rico also indicated appellant was present during the shooting.Â  However, Tommie and appellant testified appellant was not present during the shooting.
Given the conflicting evidence on both charges, the trial court appropriately submitted the charges to the jury and properly denied the directed verdict motion.Â  See State v. Curtis, supra (defendant not entitled to directed verdict when State has produced evidence of offense charged; if there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove guilt of accused, Court must find case was properly submitted to jury).
III. Illegal Drugs as Subject of Armed Robbery
Appellant argues the trial court erred by failing to direct a verdict in his favor on accessory before the fact to armed robbery where the alleged subject of the armed robbery was a quantity of illegal narcotics.Â  However, illegal drugs may be the subject of an armed robbery.Â  See, e.g., State v. Oliver, 434 S.E.2d 202 (N.C. 1993) (drugs may be subject of armed robbery); Guy v. State, 839 P.2d 578 (Nev. 1992), cert. denied, 507 U.S. 1009 (1993) (drugs can be subject of robbery).
Appellant also argues the State did not introduce any testimony regarding the value of the narcotics.Â  However, Tommie testified the cocaine taken from the victimâ€™s home had a value of approximately $9,000.Â  Accordingly, the State introduced evidence that something of value had been taken from the victim.
AFFIRMED. 
TOAL, C.J., WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

While perhaps not a complete listing of all the cases affected by this decision, the following cases are overruled to the extent they combine the concept of the sufficiency of an indictment and the concept of subject matter jurisdiction, i.e. a trial courtâ€™s power to hear a charge:

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.
I agree with the majority that the question of the sufficiency of an indictment is not a matter of subject matter jurisdiction, and that in this case the indictments, while flawed, were sufficient to confer jurisdiction.Â  I write separately, however, because in my view the circuit court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to conduct a trial of a criminal charge where there has been no presentment of an indictment by the grand jury.Â  See State v. Evans, 307 S.C. 477, 415 S.E.2d 816 (1992) (valid indictment or waiver of presentment prerequisite for circuit courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction).Â  Further, in my view, the circuit court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to accept a plea of guilty unless there has been a presentment or a written waiver of presentment.Â  S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 11; State v. Lazarus, 83 S.C. 215, 65 S.E. 270 (1909); S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-23-120 to -150 (1985); compare e.g., State v. Mitchell, 1 Bay (1 S.C.L.) 267 (1792) (S.C. Const. art. 3, Â§2, required serious criminal cases come before the court of general jurisdiction â€œthrough the medium of a grand jury, by indictmentâ€).
In my view, the majority misapprehends the function of an indictment when it holds that its purpose is merely to serve as notice to the defendant of the charges against him.Â  An indictment serves multiple functions:Â  â€œto enable the accused to repel or rebut the charge, to protect him from a future prosecution for the same charge,[11]and to enable the court to pronounce its judgment.â€Â  State v. Halder, 2 McCord (13 S.C. L.) 377 (1823).Â  While it may be that the first and second reasons for requiring an indictment inure solely to the defendantâ€™s benefit, and therefore may be waived by him, the third requirement is for the benefit of the circuit court, and is not subject to waiver by the defendant. Compare State v. Pollard, 255 S.C. 339, 179 S.E.2d 21 (1971) (defendant may waive constitutional provision intended for his benefit).Â  Further, unlike the other state constitutional provisions which benefit an accused,[12] Article I, Â§ 11 contains a limitation on waiver:Â  The last sentence of this section states â€œThe General Assembly may provide for the waiver of an indictment by the accused.â€Â  Pursuant to this grant of authority, the legislature has enacted statutory waiver provisions.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-23-120 through -150.Â  In my opinion, we must honor the limitation on an accusedâ€™s right to waive the requirements of this constitutional provision.[13]Â  Finally, even if we were to find that a defendant might waive this constitutional requirement, such a waiver would be valid only if made knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily.Â  I am concerned about the increase in post-conviction filings that would result from our abandonment of the requirement of an indictment or a written waiver of presentment, the resulting appellate proceedings, and the inevitable grants of relief.Â  I believe the limited resources of the judicial branch are better served by requiring compliance on the front end with this clear, unambiguous, and long-standing constitutional prerequisite to a criminal proceeding.[14]Â Â Â  
 I also disagree with the majorityâ€™s decision to affirm the denial of appellantâ€™s directed verdict motions on the charges of accessory before the fact.Â  I take a more expansive view of what constitutes presence at the scene than does the majority.Â  Appellant accompanied the codefendants to the scene and entered the home with prior knowledge of their plan to commit a crime.Â  â€œPresence at the scene by prearrangement to aid, encourage, or abet in the perpetration of the crime constitutes guilt as a principal.â€Â  State v. Leonard, 292 S.C. 133, 355 S.E.2d 270 (1987).Â  It is not necessary that the person participate in the actual crime or even observe it in order to be â€œpresent at the sceneâ€ and guilty as a principal.Â  See, e.g., State v. Gates, 269 S.C. 557, 238 S.E.2d 680 (1977) (getaway driver guilty as principal in armed robbery).Â  In my opinion, the evidence here is susceptible only of the inference that appellant was present at the scene aiding, encouraging, and/or abetting the codefendants, and therefore the directed verdicts should have been granted.Â  State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 447 S.E.2d 175 (1993) (absence from scene is element of accessory before the fact).
For the reasons given above, I respectfully dissent.

[1]The elements which must concur to justify the conviction of one as an accessory before the fact are as follows:Â  (1) that the defendant advised and agreed, or urged the parties or in some way aided them, to commit the offense; (2) that the defendant was not present when the offense was committed; and (3) that the principal committed the crime.Â  State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 447 S.E.2d 175 (1993) (emphasis added). 
[2]Cotton argued that because his federal indictment omitted the threshold levels of drug quantity that enhances the statutory maximum sentence, the trial court was without jurisdiction to impose a sentence for an offense not charged in the indictment.
[3]Cert. denied, 379 U.S. 868 (1964).
[4]See also Mathis v. State, 355 S.C. 87, 584 S.E.2d 366 (2003) (in finding court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to convict petitioner of first degree burglary, this Court stated S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-90 (2003) applies to indictment defects that do not affect the subject matter jurisdiction of the circuit court and does not limit a courtâ€™s consideration of indictment defects that affect subject matter jurisdiction, no matter when such issues are raised).
[5]But see State v. Carroll, 30 S.C. 85, 8 S.E. 433 (1889) (implying question of jurisdiction raised where indictment missing element of the offense).
[6]We note that a presentment of an indictment or a waiver of presentment is not needed to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the circuit court.Â  However, an indictment is needed to give notice to the defendant of the charge(s) against him.Â  See S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 11 (â€œNo person may be held to answer for any crime the jurisdiction over which is not within the magistrateâ€™s court, unless on a presentment or indictment of a grand jury of the county where the crime has been committed . . .â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-10 (2003) (â€œNo person shall be held to answer in any court for an alleged crime or offense, unless upon indictment by a grand jury . . . .â€).Â  A defendant must object if he is not presented with the indictment or if he has not waived his right to presentment.Â  If the defendant does not object, he is deemed to have waived the right to presentment.Â  See State v. Pollard, 255 S.C. 339, 179 S.E.2d 21Â  (1971) (individual may waive any provision of the Constitution intended for his benefit).
[7]See Appendix. 
[8]Few jurisdictions combine the concepts of subject matter jurisdiction of the trial court and the sufficiency of the indictment.Â  See, e.g., Ex parte Cole v. State, 842 So.2d 605 (Ala. 2002) (when first-degree robbery indictment fails to set forth essential element of offense of second-degree robbery, insufficiency of factual basis for guilty plea to second-degree robbery may be attacked on basis court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to accept the plea); State v. Bullock, 574 S.E.2d 17 (N.C. App. 2002) (when indictment does not allege essential elements of crime charged, trial court does not have subject matter jurisdiction); State v. Presler, 176 N.E.2d 308 (Ohio App. 1960) (court did not have subject matter jurisdiction where indictment did not state element of the offense). 
[9]Armed robbery occurs when a person commits robbery, which is defined as the felonious or unlawful taking of money, goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of another or in his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear, while armed with a deadly weapon.Â  Joseph v. State, 351 S.C. 551, 571 S.E.2d 280 (2002).
[10]Abrogated on other grounds by Simpson v. State, 329 S.C. 43, 495 S.E.2d 429 (1998). 
[11] A claim of double jeopardy is ordinarily judged by comparing the allegations made in the second indictment with those made in the first.Â  E.g., State v. Shirer, 20 S.C. 392 (1894).
[12] Compare S.C. Const. art. VI, Â§8, permitting governor to suspend certain public officers upon indictment, â€œor upon the waiver of such indictment if permitted by law . . . .â€
[13]It is the right to waive presentment, as provided by statute, that is the personal right of the accused and he may waive only the place of its execution, not the execution itself.Â  State v. Evans, supra.
[14] The Constitutional requirement that no man be tried on serious criminal charges save upon the grand juryâ€™s presentment of a true billed indictment has its roots in the English common law.Â  As this Court acknowledged in 1932:

  The Grand Jury is of very ancient origin in the history of England . . .it was at the time of the settlement of this country an informing and accusing body only . . . And in the struggles which in those times arose in England between the powers of the King and the rights of the subject, it often stood as a barrier against persecution in his name.

After pleading guilty to one count of willful failure to make and file a state income tax return, petitioner was placed on interim suspension. In the Matter of Thornton, 339 S.C. 22, 528 S.E.2d 657 (2000). As a result of his conviction, petitioner was thereafter suspended from the practice of law for ninety (90) days, retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.[1] In the Matter of Thornton, 340 S.C. 392, 532 S.E.2d 282 (2000). 
 In September 2000, petitioner was suspended from the practice of law for six months and one day for failure to pay court reporter fees. In the Matter of Thornton, 342 S.C. 440, 538 S.E.2d 4 (2000). This suspension was retroactive to the date of petitioner’s interim suspension in the tax matter. Id. This suspension provided petitioner would not be eligible for reinstatement until completing the terms of any probation and/or incarceration imposed in the tax matter. Id. 
 In 2002, the Court suspended petitioner from the practice of law for nine (9) months for misconduct which included accepting a loan from a client, failing to properly submit an invoice for attorneys’ fees with the Social Security Administration, and failing to properly obtain and execute a judgment. In the Matter of Thornton, 349 S.C. 55, 562 S.E.2d 316 (2002). 
 Petitioner filed this petition to be reinstated to the practice of law pursuant to Rule 33, Rule 413, SCACR. The CCF recommends petitioner be reinstated to the practice of law upon certain conditions. No exceptions were filed.

   Prior to his reinstatement, petitioner must submit proof of his compliance with continuing legal education requirements, including payment of fees, for 2003 and 2004.   During the first year of petitioner’s reinstatement, Dr. Thrasher must submit quarterly reports to the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC). During the second year of petitioner’s reinstatement, Dr. Thrasher must submit semi-annual reports to the ODC. Dr. Thrasher’s submissions shall report petitioner’s treatment and progress. In the event the reports are not filed or petitioner fails to make satisfactory progress with his treatment, ODC shall immediately notify this Court.

Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina Constitution, and at the request of the South Carolina Bar, we hereby amend Rule 34 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, to state that an attorney who is disbarred, suspended or transferred to incapacity inactive status in this State cannot be employed directly or indirectly by a member of the South Carolina Bar as a paralegal, investigator or in any capacity connected with the practice of law nor be employed directly or indirectly in the State as a paralegal, investigator or in any capacity connected with the practice of law by a lawyer licensed in any other jurisdiction.

 Columbia , South Carolina

  RULE 34
  EMPLOYMENT OF DISBARRED OR SUSPENDED LAWYERS
 A lawyer who is disbarred, suspended or transferred to incapacity inactive status shall not be employed directly or indirectly by a member of the South Carolina Bar as a paralegal, investigator or in any other capacity connected with the practice of law nor be employed directly or indirectly in the State of South Carolina as a paralegal, investigator or in any capacity connected with the practice of law by a lawyer licensed in any other jurisdiction. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Luke A. Williams, III,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,        Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Edgefield County
Marc H. Westbrook, Post-Conviction Judge
Luke Brown, Trial Judge

Opinion No. 25950
Submitted February 16, 2005 - Filed March 14, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
David I. Bruck and Robert Edward Lominack, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted certiorari to review a post-conviction relief (PCR) order granting respondent a new capital sentencing proceeding, finding his trial counsel was ineffective in failing to request a â€œplain and ordinaryâ€ meaning jury charge.[1]Â  We find that counselâ€™s performance was deficient, but that there is no evidence of resulting prejudice.Â  We therefore reverse the PCR order.
FACTS
Respondent was convicted of murdering his wife and his son and received two death sentences.Â  His direct appeal was affirmed.Â  State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 327, 468 S.E.2d 626 (1996).Â  At the PCR hearing, trial counsel acknowledged that there was no strategic or tactical reason why he failed to request a â€œplain meaningâ€ charge.Â  The PCR judge granted relief, and the State sought a writ of certiorari to review that decision.
ISSUE

Whether there is any evidence in the record to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that respondent received ineffective assistance of counsel in the sentencing phase of his capital trial?

ANALYSIS
A PCR applicant claiming trial counsel rendered ineffective assistance must demonstrate that (1) counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness and (2) but for counselâ€™s error, there is a reasonable probability that the outcome of the proceeding would have been different.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 688 (1984); Sellers v. State, ___ S.C. ___, 607 S.E.2d 82 (2005).Â  In other words, the applicant must establish both error and prejudice.Â  Id.Â  On appellate review, this Court will uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law if there is any evidence of probative value in the record to support them.Â  Id.
The PCR judge found that trial counselâ€™s testimony established the error prong of the ineffective assistance test.Â  We agree.Â  He found resulting prejudice from the failure to give â€œthe plain meaningâ€ charge because:

1)     respondent had no prior criminal record;
2)     respondent had been out on bond prior to the trial and remained out until the guilty verdicts were returned; and
3)     the penalty phase evidence was predominately circumstantial, far from overwhelming, and the State had primarily relied on this weak evidence in aggravation during the penalty phase.

We disagree.
We have carefully considered whether the record supports the PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion that respondent was prejudiced by the lack of a plain meaning charge, and conclude it does not.Â  While the factors cited by the PCR judge might support a prejudice finding in some cases, they do not in the context of this case.Â  The evidence, albeit circumstantial, showed that respondent and his wife were experiencing significant marital problems and financial difficulties, and had in fact declared bankruptcy and seen foreclosure proceedings initiated against their marital home.Â  In May 1991, respondent substantially increased life insurance benefits on his wife and child, naming himself as beneficiary.Â  He also forged wifeâ€™s signature on an automobile insurance form in the course of increasing that coverage.Â  On June 19, the bodies of respondentâ€™s wife and son were found in the family car, which had been partially burned.Â  The wife had died of blunt head traumaÂ  consistent with that inflicted by a human fist, and son had been strangled.Â  Respondent had hand injuries consistent with beating, and told others the causes of death prior to receiving autopsy results.
We do not agree with the PCR judgeâ€™s characterization of the evidence of respondentâ€™s guilt as weak.Â  Further, the evidence demonstrated that respondentâ€™s motives were financial gain and the elimination of his domestic problems.Â  Having achieved what he set out to accomplish, it is not surprising or meaningful that respondent met the obligations of his bond.Â  Further, given the nature of these crimes, we find the fact that he had no prior criminal record irrelevant to the question whether he was prejudiced by the lack of a â€œplain meaningâ€ charge.
The jury, by its guilty verdicts, found respondent planned in cold blood the deaths of his child and his wife, making arrangements to benefit financially.Â  Further, the â€œplain meaningâ€ charge evolved from the Courtâ€™s concern that capital juries were speculating about parole eligibility.Â  See Southerland v. State, footnote 1, supra.Â Â  There is nothing in this record to indicate that the jurors in respondentâ€™s capital trial were concerned with parole eligibility, or confused about the meaning of a life sentence.Â  We hold there is no evidence in the record to support the PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion that respondent was prejudiced by trial counselâ€™s deficient performance, that is, that had the jury been given a â€œplain meaningâ€ charge there is a reasonable possibility that it would have returned two life sentences.Â  Sellers v. State, supra.
CONCLUSION
Finding no evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion that respondent was prejudiced by the lack of a â€œplain meaningâ€ charge, the order granting respondent a new sentencing proceeding is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] It is well settled that a capital defendant is entitled upon request to a jury charge in the sentencing phase of his trial that the term life imprisonment is to be understood in its plain and ordinary meaning.Â  See Southerland v. State, 337 S.C. 610, 524 S.E.2d 833 (1999) (reviewing the history of the â€œplain meaningâ€ charge).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Richard Wehle, Jerry Miller and the Town of Wellford, on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated,       
Respondents-Plaintiffs,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The South Carolina Retirement System and the South Carolina Budget and Control Board,       
Petitioners-Defendants.
      
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No. 25951
Heard January 20, 2005 - Filed March 21, 2005

JUDGMENT FOR DEFENDANTS


  
    
      
Gedney M. Howe, III, of Law Offices of Gedney M. Howe, III, P.A., of Charleston; A. Camden Lewis, of Lewis, Babcock & Hawkins, L.L.P.; and Michael E. Spears, of Michael E. Spears, P.A., of Spartanburg, for respondents-plaintiffs.
Richard M. Gergel and W. Allen Nickles, III, of Gergel, Nickles & Solomon, P.A.; Stephen Van Camp, of South Carolina Retirement Systems, Edwin E. Evans, of S.C. Budget and Control Board; and Kent Porth, of Nexsen, Pruet, Jacobs & Pollard, LLP, all of Columbia, for petitioners-defendants.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This case is before us in our original jurisdiction asking that we construe S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-10(4) (Supp. 2003) which determines how unused annual leave is figured into the calculation of state retirement benefits.Â  
We recently construed this provision in Kennedy v. South Carolina Retirement System, 345 S.C. 339, 549 S.E.2d 243 (2001).Â  Kennedy involved the computation of â€œaverage final compensationâ€ which is one of the factors used to calculate monthly state retirement benefits.Â  Until 1978, average final compensation was defined under Â§ 9-1-10(17) as:Â  

the average annual earnable compensation of a member during the three consecutive fiscal years of his creditable service producing the highest average.

As a matter of policy, retiring employees were given credit for unused annual leave in whatever amount had accrued although there was no statutory requirement that such credit be given.
In 1978, the legislature amended Â§ 9-1-10(17) by adding a specific provision regarding unused annual leave:

an amount up to and including forty-five days termination pay for unused annual leave may be added to the pay period immediately prior to retirement and included in the average as applicable.

In 1986, the legislature amended this provision regarding unused annual leave:

An amount up to and including forty-five days termination pay for unused annual leave at retirement may be added to the average final compensation.

The plaintiffs in Kennedy claimed the change in the underscored language meant that the credit for unused annual leave should be added after the average final compensation is calculated, rather than simply factored into the average as previously provided, resulting in an increased benefit.Â  The trial court found against the plaintiffs on August 19, 1997.Â  On May 22, 2000, we issued our opinion reversing.Â  
We granted rehearing in Kennedy, and on December 5, 2000, extensive oral arguments were heard.Â  On May 22, 2001, we refiled our opinion, this time finding in favor of the Retirement System.Â  We held the legislature could not have intended to bestow a benefit on retirees adding $1.177 billion in liability to the Retirement System without any fiscal impact analysis, floor debate, or the provision of additional funding.Â  We concluded the employeesâ€™ interpretation of the statute would lead to the absurd result of rendering the Retirement System actuarially unsound.Â  Rehearing was denied on July 23, 2001.
Meanwhile, on May 11, 2000, before our original Kennedy opinion was issued, an amendment to the 2000-2001 Appropriations Bill was introduced.Â  The amendment recodified the definitions found in Â§ 9-1-10 and alphabetized them.Â  The definition of average final compensation was renumbered as subsection (4) rather than (17), but otherwise it remained unchanged.Â  This amended provision was ratified as part of the Appropriations Bill in Part II, Â§ 67, Act No. 387, on June 22, 2000, one month after our initial decision in Kennedy.
The action now before us was commenced on September 24, 2001, two months after we refused to rehear the final Kennedy decision.Â  Plaintiffs filed this case as a class action in Colleton County circuit court.Â  The complaint alleges that the Retirement System has failed to add a credit for unused annual leave up to forty-five days to the average final compensation as required by the 1986 amendment to Â§ 9-1-10(17); further, the failure to pay this additional benefit has resulted in overfunding the Retirement System in breach of the Systemâ€™s fiduciary duty.Â  Plaintiffs claim their position is supported by the legislatureâ€™s ratification of the same definition of average final compensation on June 18, 2000, after our initial Kennedy opinion which construed that definition in favor of the employees.Â  Plaintiffs seek payment of the amounts purportedly withheld illegally since 1986.Â  
On October 25, 2001, defendants petitioned this Court to take the case in our original jurisdiction which we granted on December 4, 2001.Â  We appointed then Circuit Judge John W. Kittredge as referee.Â  Judge Kittredge filed his report on February 24, 2004, recommending the complaint be dismissed with prejudice.Â  After careful consideration of the briefs and oral argument in this case, we hereby adopt Judge Kittredgeâ€™s recommendations as reported below and enter judgment for defendants.Â  Footnotes indicated by an asterisk are ours.
REFEREEâ€™S ORDER
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The South Carolina Retirement Systems (collectively, the â€œSystemâ€) service several groups of state employees, active and retired.Â  Of the four separate pension funds administered by the South Carolina Budget and Control Board (the Board), this case concerns the two largest funds, consisting of approximately 200,000 active employees and approximately 80,000 former employees in retired status.Â  The South Carolina Retirement System (SCRS) is comprised of state employees, public school teachers and local governmental employees.Â  This action further involves the Police Officer Retirement System (PORS).[1]Â  The SCRS, as of July 2001, had a market value well in excess of $18 billion.
The System is administered under an elaborate statutory and constitutional scheme designed to protect the independence, integrity and actuarial soundness of the funds.Â  The Board is directed to appoint a plan actuary whose responsibilities include the preparation of annual actuarial valuation.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 9-1-230, -240, -260 (1986).Â  The actuarial valuation establishes the foundation for the determination of employer contribution rates and the ongoing monitoring of the actuarial soundness of the various components of the System.Â  The employee contribution rate is set by the General Assembly and the employer rate is set by the Board upon the advice of the plan actuary and the findings and conclusions of the annual actuarial valuation.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-1020 (Supp. 2003).Â  The actuarial valuation is relied upon in the preparation of the Stateâ€™s annual financial statement and by outside entities in rating the State for purposes of issuance of bonds.
South Carolina Constitution, Article X, Â§ 16, grants the Board broad powers to protect the fiscal integrity of the retirement funds.Â  Since 1979, the Board has been empowered to determine that no benefit increase granted by the General Assembly can be implemented until the Board first determines that â€œfunding for such increase on a sound actuarial basis has been provided or is currently provided.â€Â  Section 16 also provides that should the Board determine that any retirement system is not funded on a sound actuarial basis, the General Assembly must provide funding necessary to restore the fiscal integrity of the System.Â  This constitutional provision further protects the accounts of the System from being used for any purpose other than the payment of retirement benefits.Â  In this manner, the fiscal integrity of the System is entrusted to the Board, which relies upon its plan actuary to value, on an annual basis, its ability to provide benefits.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-230 (1986).
In this action, Plaintiffs seek to re-open and modify official valuations prepared by the plan actuary and relied upon by the Board and General Assembly.Â  Since 1986, the General Assembly has enacted substantial enhancements to retirement benefits, relying upon the official valuations prepared in keeping with the authority delegated to the Board and the plan actuary by statutes and by the Stateâ€™s Constitution.Â  While the granting of relief to Plaintiffs may have unsettling implications in terms of the Stateâ€™s financial condition and the present ability of the system to absorb more debt, Plaintiffs have correctly challenged the Systemâ€™s â€œscare tacticsâ€ at every turn.Â  The success of Plaintiffsâ€™ claim depends solely on the matter of legislative intent.
The dispositive issue here, as it was in Kennedy v. South Carolina Retirement System, 345 S.C. 339, 549 S.E.2d 243 (2001), is determining the legislative intent in the General Assemblyâ€™s 1986 amendment to the calculation of â€œaverage final compensation,â€ currently codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-10(4) (Supp. 2003).
The South Carolina General Assembly amended the definition of â€œaverage final compensationâ€ in 1986 to allow members of the Retirement System to retire throughout the year, rather than require essentially all retirements to occur on June 30, the last day of the fiscal year.Â  As expressly stated in the title of the bill that gave rise to this amendment, its purpose was to â€œchange the definition of average final compensation from average earnable compensation of a member during three consecutive fiscal years to twelve consecutive quarters.â€Â  1986 S.C. Act No. 540.Â  No mention was made in the title of the bill of an intent to increase or alter retirement benefits or the benefit formula in any manner.Â  Further, there was no legislative debate or record suggesting that the amendment was in any way associated with a benefit or formula change, and no fiscal impact statement was prepared or provided, which would have been required if there were to be any increase in retirement benefits and costs.
Although inartfully drawn, a member at retirement was allowed to add up to forty-five days of unused annual leave to his or her final pay period, which may or may not have been included in the three highest consecutive fiscal years of salary for purposes of computing the â€œaverage final compensation.â€
Prior to 1986, â€œaverage final compensationâ€ was defined as follows:

(17) â€œAverage final compensationâ€ with respect to those members retiring on or after July 1, 1970, shall mean the average annual earnable compensation of a member during the three consecutive fiscal years of his creditable service producing the highest such average; an amount up to and including forty-five days termination pay for unused annual leave may be added to the pay period immediately prior to retirement and included in the average as applicable.

In 1986, the amendment read as follows:

(17) â€œAverage final compensationâ€ with respect to those members retiring on or after July 1, 1986, shall mean the average annual earnable compensation of a member during the twelve consecutive quarters of his creditable service on which regular contributions as a member were made to the System producing the highest such average; a quarter means a period January through March, April through June, July though September, or October through December.Â  An amount up to and including forty-five daysâ€™ termination pay for unused annual leave at retirement may be added to the average final compensation.

Upon adoption of the amendment, the System interpreted the statute to allow retirement at the end of any quarter and computed the â€œaverage final compensationâ€ to be the twelve highest consecutive quarters of salary.Â  Up to forty-five days of unused annual leave could be added as â€œtermination payâ€ and included in the computation of â€œaverage final compensationâ€ regardless of which twelve quarters of compensation were used.Â  For nine years this consistent administrative interpretation went unquestioned by thousands of state employees as they qualified for retirement.
The Kennedy suit was commenced in 1995.Â  As noted, the Supreme Court rejected the employeesâ€™ position and held that the â€œGeneral Assembly intended the forty-five days of unused annual leave to be added to the computation [of average final compensation] before taking the average of the 12 highest quarters.â€Â  Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 348, 549 S.E.2d at 247 (emphasis in original).Â  Plaintiffs here seek to avoid the holding in Kennedy by arguing that the proposed benefit is â€œaffordable.â€
RECOMMENDATION
Having carefully considered the record, I am firmly convinced that the General Assemblyâ€™s intent in 1986 in amending the definition of â€œaverage final compensationâ€ is precisely as determined in Kennedy.Â  I recommend the Court reject Plaintiffsâ€™ position pursuant to the doctrine of stare decisis.Â  Should the Court desire to revisit the merits of the claim in Kennedy, I recommend dismissal of the complaint for two primary reasons:Â  (1) the matter of legislative intent is not a moving target; and (2) the issue of affordability is largely irrelevant to a determination of legislative intent.
ANALYSIS
I.Â  Stare Decisis
The Court should honor the Kennedy precedent and dismiss Plaintiffsâ€™ action, which seeks to relitigate the identical issue, pursuant to the doctrine of stare decisis.Â  The doctrine of stare decisis enjoys particular efficacy in the context of challenges concerning the construction of statutes and determination of legislative intent.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  As noted by the Court:

It is manifestly in the public interest that the law remain permanently settled.Â  Especially is this so in the construction of statutes, for if any change in the statutory law is desired, the General Assembly may readily accomplish it.

Powers v. Powers, 239 S.C. 423, 427, 123 S.E.2d 646, 647 (1962).
In the event the Court elects to address the merits of Plaintiffsâ€™ claim, I offer the following analysis.
II.Â  Legislative Intent
The determination of legislative intent is a matter of law.Â  City of Myrtle Beach v. Juel P. Corp., 344 S.C. 43, 543 S.E.2d 538 (2001); Charleston County Parks and Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d 841 (1995).Â  Legislative intent, once determined, is â€œpermanently settledâ€ absent subsequent action by the General Assembly to effect a change in the statutory law.Â  Powers, 239 S.C. at 427, 123 S.E.2d at 647.Â  Either Kennedy is good law or it is not.Â  Plaintiffs certainly cannot be heard to argue that the General Assembly in 1986 intended one result for the Kennedy plaintiffs and another result in this action.Â  As Kennedy goes, so go these Plaintiffs.Â  In my firm judgment, the record before me serves only to reaffirm the holding in Kennedy.Â  I find the evidence concerning legislative history clearly preponderates contrary to Plaintiffsâ€™ position.Â  In so finding, I rely heavily on the sound reasoning of the Kennedy court.
â€œThe most powerful indication of legislative intent is the lack of legislative history and debate which accompaniedâ€ the change in the definition of â€œaverage final compensation.â€Â  Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 348, 549 S.E.2d at 247.Â  As the Court further stated:

The history in no way indicates the legislature intended to make such a dramatic increase in benefits.Â  First, the title of the 1986 Appropriations Act, which included the amendment . . . did not reference an increase in benefits.Â  [footnote omitted].Â  See Ex Parte Georgetown County Water & Sewer Dist., 284 S.C. 466, 468-69, 327 S.E.2d 654, 656 (1985) (â€œThe purpose of Article III, Â§ 17 is to prevent the General Assembly from being misled into the passage of bills containing provisions not indicated in their titles.â€) . . . .Â Â Â  The plain language of the title gives no indication or notice that the amendment would triple the dollar value for unused annual leave.
Secondly, had the General Assembly intended to increase benefits and spend $1.177 billion, it is reasonable to assume they would have engaged in floor debate.Â  They did not.Â  [footnote omitted].Â  Furthermore, no fiscal impact analysis was undertaken.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 2-7-72 (Supp.1999) (Bills and resolutions requiring expenditure of funds shall have impact statements).Â  [footnote omitted].Â  Finally, the legislature did not determine whether the increase would impact the actuarial soundness of the State Retirement System as a whole.Â  While we hold the amendment to section 9-1-10(17) does not violate S.C. Const. art. X, Â§ 16, the fact that the legislature has never funded the increase as required by article X, Â§ 16 is further evidence the legislature did not intend to bestow such an increase when it amended [the definition].

Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 349, 549 S.E.2d at 248.
An additional factor weighing against Plaintiffsâ€™ position is that application of such interpretation â€œwould allow members to retire with benefits calculated on an â€˜averageâ€™ salary which is greater than any salary they earned during employment.â€Â  Id.Â  Another consequence would be the exclusion of most public school teachers (who generally do not acquire unused annual leave) from the proposed benefit.Â  It is difficult to imagine that the legislature would intend such a dramatic benefit increase and purposefully exclude teachers from the increased benefit.Â  Certainly, those representing teachers would not sit idly by while all other employee groups were bestowed with an unprecedented and unrequested retirement benefit increase.[2]
In 1986, the cost of the proposed benefit increase would have been $350 million dollars.Â  It borders on frivolity to suggest that the General Assembly intended to spend $350 million dollars on an unprecedented and unrequested benefit without any meaningful discussion.Â  There was neither floor debate nor controversy nor rancor nor funding, for the simple reason the General Assembly never intended the so-called Kennedy benefit.Â  Moreover, the post-Kennedy legislative inaction lends further support to this conclusion.Â  See Wigfall v. Tideland Utilities, Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 580 S.E.2d 100 (2003) (recognizing the presumption that the legislature is aware of court interpretation of statutes, and construing legislative inaction as evidence of the legislatureâ€™s concurrence with the courtâ€™s interpretation); State v. 192 Coin-Operated Video Game Machines, 338 S.C. 176, 525 S.E.2d 872 (2000) (noting the presumption that the legislature is aware of court interpretation of statutes).
Plaintiffs assert the General Assembly â€œadoptedâ€ the initial Kennedy opinion issued by the Supreme Court on May 22, 2000.Â  Plaintiffsâ€™ argument overlooks the fact that the initial Kennedy decision was never final.Â  It is the General Assemblyâ€™s inaction following the entry of the final judgment in Kennedy which is entitled to consideration.*
It is on the issue of funding where Plaintiffs seek to revisit Kennedy Â through the back door.Â  Indeed, the Kennedy plaintiffs sought rehearing on the contention that the General Assembly in 1986 provided the funding mechanism for the proposed increase in retirement benefits by the elimination of the longevity pay program.Â  The rehearing petition was denied.Â  Kennedy v. South Carolina Retirement System, 349 S.C. 531, 564 S.E.2d 322 (2001).Â  The next line of attack on Kennedy is an independent action to set aside the judgment alleging fraud on the court.Â  For purposes of the present claim, this leads to the focus of Plaintiffsâ€™ case, the issue of affordability.3
III.Â  Affordability
Plaintiffsâ€™ â€œaffordabilityâ€ argument has expanded well beyond the idea that the funding for the claimed retirement benefit was contemplated in the elimination of the longevity benefit in 1986.Â  The transparent weakness of the position that the new benefit was â€œswappedâ€ for the elimination of the prior benefit, I believe, has forced Plaintiffs to scurry for cover in other areas.Â  In this regard, Plaintiffs seek to scrutinize many of the actions and decisions of the plan actuaries, the Board and others since 1986, and in some instances even prior to 1986.Â  While I do find the proposed benefit was affordable in 1986, Plaintiffsâ€™ claims of affordability are otherwise manifestly without merit.4
The assertion that the 1986 proposed benefit tripling the value of unused annual leave was a â€œswapâ€ for the 1986 elimination of the longevity benefit can be dealt with in short order.Â  As noted, the cost of the proposed benefit in 1986 was $350 million; today, the figure is far in excess of $1 billion.Â  The savings to the System as a result of the elimination of the longevity benefit was de minimus.Â  For example, in an experience study from 1980 to 1985, of the 4,416 state employees who retired, only 132 (or 2.86%) qualified for the longevity benefit.Â  Plaintiffs do not dispute these figures but simply argue that a five-year study is not a sufficiently â€œmature experience.â€Â  Assuming the accuracy of these figures, even Plaintiffsâ€™ retained actuary, Mr. James Berberian, concedes the modest savings (the so-called â€œactuarial gainâ€) from eliminating longevity pay would have a â€œsmaller impactâ€ and be insufficient to pay the staggering costs associated with the tripling of the value of unused annual leave.5Â  There is absolutely no nexus between the discontinuance of the longevity pay program and the change in definition of â€œaverage final compensation,â€ other than that both items appear in the 1986 Appropriations Act consisting of more than 950 pages.*
The fact remains the benefit was affordable in 1986, and the System offers only token resistance to this indisputable fact.6Â  Quite frankly, I view the affordability of the proposed benefit in 1986 as much ado about nothing.Â  The System couldÂ  â€œaffordâ€ many things in 1986 that it most probably could not today.7Â  The critical inquiry is the intent of the General Assembly in 1986 in amending the definition of â€œaverage final compensation.â€Â  To bootstrap an affirmative finding of legislative intent on the mere affordability of the proposed benefit in 1986 would require the court to ignore the factors typically considered in determining legislative intent, as discussed above, which uniformly lead to the conclusion that the General Assembly in 1986 did not intend the proposed benefit.*
Except for Plaintiffsâ€™ argument concerning 1986, their affordability claim is otherwise premised on challenges to the methodologies and assumptions utilized by the responsible parties, including the plan actuaries and the Board.Â Â  While Plaintiffsâ€™ broad brush attack implicates virtually every facet of the System, only three areas warrant discussion:Â  the determination of (1) the â€œnormal cost contribution;â€ (2) the methodologies to ensure that payment of a future benefit (unfunded actuarial accrued liability, or â€œUAALâ€) is accomplished within the thirty-year liquidation period; and (3) an appropriate â€œloadâ€ factor.Â  These issues, to be sure, are not mutually exclusive, for there exists critical interplay between each of these areas.
Plaintiffs in general argue that the System, through its actuaries and the Board, has intentionally miscalculated its assets and liabilities to create the illusion that the purported benefit is not affordable.Â  More specifically, Plaintiffs assert that the System has improperly and artificially increased the Stateâ€™s contribution to â€œnormal cost,â€ which has the effect of reducing funds available for the employer portion attributable to UAAL to fund future payments.Â  There is no credible evidence to support these arguments.Â  To the contrary, the credible evidence compellingly demonstrates that the professionals charged with managing the System have discharged their duties responsibly and with a commitment to ensure the continued stability and soundness of the Stateâ€™s various pension funds.
Retirement benefits are funded by contributions from the employee and employer.Â  â€œNormal costâ€ represents that portion of the employerâ€™s contribution, as determined by the Board, necessary to pay the anticipated benefits of active members.Â  For example, in 2001 the contribution levels [were] (i) employee contributions of 6.0% and (ii) employer contributions of 7.55% for State employees and teachers, and 6.7% for other employers.Â  The employer contribution rates are the sum of 4.61% normal cost contribution and a 2.94% (state employees and teachers) or 2.09% (other employees) contribution intended to amortize the unfunded liability.Â  (Defendantsâ€™ Ex. 15).Â  In properly administering the Systemâ€™s multi-billion dollar pension funds, such critical decisions should be influenced by neither unqualified experts8 nor creative lawyering.Â  Plaintiffs suggest that a minor change in the â€œnormal cost contributionâ€ from 4.61% to 4% (with a corresponding increase in the UAAL contribution for funding of future benefits) would make the Kennedy benefit affordable.Â  Under Plaintiffsâ€™ approach, any proposed benefit can appear affordable on paper, provided one is not too concerned with the integrity and overall soundness of the System.Â  The reality is that ostensibly slight changes to the contribution levels can dramatically affect the Systemâ€™s soundness, especially in ensuring that future benefits are paid within the thirty-year liquidation period.
The unfunded accrued liability liquidation period serves as another area where Plaintiffsâ€™ proposals would push the system to the edge, and perhaps beyond.Â  In fact, I am persuaded that Plaintiffsâ€™ proposals (to make the Kennedy benefit affordable) would defeat the Systemâ€™s ability to comply with the thirty-year liquidation period.Â  Plaintiffs claim that the retirement plans are â€œoverfundedâ€ as a result of â€œexcessive contributions,â€ leading to a â€œsurplus.â€Â  This argument cannot withstand scrutiny.Â  Plaintiffsâ€™ actuaries concede the SCRS and the PORS had unfunded actuarial liabilities according to the 2001 Actuarial Valuations that exceeded $2.6 billion.Â  The premise of Plaintiffsâ€™ argument is that they have the right to reduce the Boardâ€™s determination of â€œnormal costâ€ and thereby shorten the liquidation period.Â  A liquidation period of less than thirty years is viewed by Plaintiffs as a â€œsurplus.â€Â  Reducing the â€œnormal cost contributionâ€ has the effect of increasing the ability of the System to absorb additional debt.Â  For example, if the liquidation period is twenty years, then the System, according to Plaintiffs, has a surplus of ten years in which to create more debt.Â  â€œOverfundingâ€ in this context merely describes a system retiring debt sooner than actuarially anticipated.Â  Reducing the â€œnormal cost contributionâ€ has this very effect.
Plaintiffs would be content to reduce the â€œnormal cost,â€ increase debt, and run the liquidation period to (and likely beyond) thirty years, while the System has opted for a more cautious approach.Â  The Systemâ€™s approach allows for a measure of flexibility in the event of lean financial times where the return on investments is less than anticipated.Â  I see absolutely no reason to find fault with the Systemâ€™s philosophy and approach, especially since the System began investing in equity markets.Â  Manipulating the â€œnormal cost contributionâ€ and UAAL portions of the employer contributions to achieve Plaintiffsâ€™ desired result would wreak havoc on the System.9
It is perhaps significant to note that the benefits supposedly purposefully enacted by the General Assembly in 1986 has no peer in the annals of United States public pension plans.Â  In this regard, even Plaintiffsâ€™ experts acknowledge that the proposed benefit has never been contemplated by any public retirement system.Â  The testimony of one of Plaintiffsâ€™ experts, Mr. Fred Bass, is particularly instructive.Â  Bass was not a credible witness.Â  His willingness to manipulate data to promote Plaintiffsâ€™ cause did not go unnoticed.Â  Bass, however, had some limits in his propensity to advocate for Plaintiffs.Â  Forced to admit that he had never seen a pension plan where unused annual leave is added after average final compensation is computed, Bass described the benefit proposed by Plantiffs as â€œextraordinary.â€
Another illustration of Plaintiffsâ€™ fast and loose approach to actuarial methodologies concerns their desire to alter the Systemâ€™s â€œloadâ€ factor.Â  Plaintiffs contend the System has already accounted for the proposed benefit through pre-funding a â€œloadâ€ of 3.5%, which they assert would have been â€œmore than enoughâ€ to cover the liability of tripling the value of unused annual leave.Â  A â€œloadâ€ is a factor calculated to project the cost of a benefit.Â  In this instance, the record indicates that prior to 1995, a 1% factor was included as a projected cost of all leave in the retirement benefit formula.Â  During the Kennedy litigation, a study was performed by the plan actuary, using a cross section of participants, to calculate an amount attributable to unused annual leave, based upon historical use.Â  This study indicated that including up to forty-five days in the average final compensation formula increased costs to the retirements systems by approximately 2.5% per year.Â  Thereafter, the 2.5% â€œloadâ€ was substituted for the earlier 1% â€œload.â€Â  The plan actuaries have never used a composite 3.5% â€œloadâ€ as argued by Plaintiffs.Â  Having never utilized the proposed 3.5% â€œload,â€ it would be highly inappropriate to retroactively modify methodologies and assumptions utilized in official valuation reports that have been relied upon by the State and others.
In rejecting the various claims of affordability, it is not my intent to disparage Plaintiffs or their excellent counsel, for it is readily apparent they embarked on the affordability abyss not entirely of their own choosing.Â  Plaintiffs perceive the Kennedy decision as revenue driven, resulting from the potential impact of recognizing the proposed benefit in the context of the present status of the System.Â  I do not read Kennedy as embracing post-1986 affordability as the benchmark for determining legislative intent.Â  In my view, Kennedy properly relied on the facts and circumstances surrounding the 1986 amendment to ascertain the intent of the General Assembly at that time.Â  The concerns with the current financial impact of the proposed benefit on the System are, at best, an adjunct to bolster the underlying determination of legislative intent.
IV.Â  Class Certification
In light of my proposed findings and recommendations, I need not address the issue of class certification.
CONCLUSION
After exhaustively reviewing this voluminous record, I come to the conclusion that the courts should be reticent to intervene in the management of the South Carolina Retirement System.Â  Absent evidence of a gross abuse of discretion, the management and administration of the South Carolina Retirement System must remain with those upon whom the law imposes the responsibility.Â  To permit present and former state employees to cherrypick preferred methodologies and financial projections to advance a particular agenda would irreparably undermine the ability of those responsible to discharge their critical duties and compromise the Stateâ€™s credibility among financial institutions and rating agencies.Â  The wisdom of protecting and maintaining constitutional independence concerning the South Carolina Retirement System is beyond serious challenge.10Â  
In sum, in light of Kennedy, the application of the doctrine of stare decisis would require dismissal of this action.Â  In any event, Plaintiffs have failed to establish that the General Assembly in 1986 intended to triple the value of unused annual leave in amending the definition of â€œaverage final compensation.â€Â  The credible evidence overwhelmingly demonstrates, just as determined by this court in Kennedy, that the forty-five days of unused annual leave should be added to the computation of â€œaverage final compensationâ€ before taking the average of the twelve highest quarters.Â  I recommend Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint be dismissed with prejudice.
 JUDGMENT FOR DEFENDANTS.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, MOORE, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice Alexander S. Macaulay, concur.

[1]The remaining two pension funds, unrelated to this case, are the Legislative Retirement System and the Judicial Retirement System.
[2] Plaintiffs assert that the proposed benefit was indeed requested by Purvis Collins, former director of the System.Â  I disagree.Â  First, the absence of direct evidence has forced Plaintiffs to resort to speculation.Â  I give little weight to such self-serving conjecture.Â  Second, just as Plaintiffs cry foul over the Systemâ€™s reliance on the current director, Peggy Boykin, to establish more recent legislative intent, Plaintiffs are similarly foreclosed from relying on Collinsâ€™s alleged motives.Â  See Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 353, 549 S.E.2d at 250 (rejecting the employeesâ€™ reliance on the testimony of Purvis Collins to establish legislative intent and recognizing the â€œsettled principle in the interpretation of statutes that even where there is some ambiguity or some uncertainty in the language used, resort cannot be had to the opinions of legislators or of others concerned in the enactment of the law, for the purpose of ascertaining the intent of the legislatureâ€).Â  Nevertheless, the Kennedy court deemed Collinsâ€™s testimony as head of the System relevant, insofar as the executive branch interpreted and administered the 1986 amendment.Â  Id.Â  This agency interpretation inures to the benefit of the Systemâ€™s position concerning legislative intent.
* Further, as we noted above, the legislatureâ€™s re-enactment of the definitions in Â§ 9-1-10 was introduced on May 11, 2000, which was before our initial decision in Kennedy while the appeal of the trial courtâ€™s decision in favor of the Retirement System was still pending.Â  This legislative action could therefore indicate an intent to confirm the trial courtâ€™s reading of the statute in favor of Retirement System and not the employees.
3 Plaintiffsâ€™ moving-target approach to legislative intent is further reflected in their attempt to merge the issue of legislative intent with that of affordability by drawing this courtâ€™s attention to the year 2000.Â  Plaintiffs assert that the â€œSystem could easily absorb more than $2 billion in new benefits in 2000.â€Â  I recommend the court reject these efforts, for the sole matter before this court is discerning the General Assemblyâ€™s intent in 1986 in amending the definition of â€œaverage final compensation.â€Â  Plaintiffs are not alone in selectively choosing certain years, for the System is willing to debate the issue of affordability in every year except 1986.
4 I address the matter of affordability for two reasons.Â  First, the parties, particularly Plaintiffs, have devoted considerable attention to the issue.Â  Second, I wish to provide the Court with a meaningful response to all issues deemed important by the parties.Â  By doing so, the Court can make its own determinations of relevancy.Â  I recommend the Court determine the matter of legislative intent on a basis other than affordability.Â  Affordability in years other than 1986 clearly has no bearing on the intent of the General Assembly in 1986.Â  Legislative inaction, however, since the final judgment in Kennedy is some evidence of the General Assemblyâ€™s concurrence with the Courtâ€™s decision.
5 I reject as meritless the testimony of Plaintiffsâ€™ expert who opined that the System saved $150 million from the elimination of the longevity benefit.
* In a similar vein, Plaintiffs rely on a memo written to Rick Kelly, Executive Director of the State Retirement Systems, from Bob Toomey, Chief Administrator of the Budget and Control Board, discussing the impact of our initial decision in Kennedy.Â  The memo recommends asking the legislative conference committee to strike a proposal guaranteeing an annual COLA increase of 1% in order to accommodate the increased benefit for unused annual leave under Kennedy.Â  Plaintiffs argue the fact that the proposed 1% guaranteed COLA was not included in the 2000 Appropriations Act demonstrates legislative intent that â€œaverage final compensationâ€ be interpreted as initially construed by the Court in Kennedy.Â  Plaintiffsâ€™ theory is simply too speculative to support a finding of legislative intent.Â  There is nothing linking an intended increase in benefits and the General Assemblyâ€™s ultimate failure to include the proposed COLA guarantee which could have been dropped for any number of reasons.
6 It appears that the unfounded accrued liability of the System was at that time slightly in excess of $200 million, with a projected amortization period of only four years, well within the thirty-year liquidation period.Â  The System was well situated in the mid to late 1980â€™s to handle new and increased retirement benefits, which were in fact added in the 1980â€™s and 1990â€™s.Â  The increase in retirement benefits, and corresponding increase in the liabilities to the System, has taken many forms, including the recognition in some years of liability associated with cost of living adjustments and otherwise.Â  In later years, more substantial benefits were added, such as the Teacher Employee Retention Incentive Program (TERI/28 ) in 2000.
7 The term â€œaffordâ€ simply reflects the Systemâ€™s then existing ability to absorb additional debt without pushing the amortization period to the brink of the thirty-year mark.Â  Moreover, had the proposed benefit been recognized and funded in 1986, we would now be looking at a vastly different history in terms of retirement benefits and increases through the years.Â  It is this inability to rewrite history that partly explains Plaintiffsâ€™ desire to alter previous yearsâ€™ contribution rates and actuarial methodologies to create an appearance of current affordability.Â  As noted at the end of this section, the affordability focus may also be traced to Plaintiffsâ€™ perceptions of the underpinnings of the Kennedy decision.Â  The simple and correct answer to this quandary is that the General Assembly in 1986 did not intend to triple the value of unused annual leave.
*A footnote in our Kennedy decision specifically states:Â  â€œAlthough we find $1.177 billion to be the correct figure, even a quarter of that figure, as suggested by the dissent, would cause dire consequences to the Retirement System.â€Â  Kennedy, 345 S.C. at 352, 549 S.E.2d at 249, n. 15.Â  The fact remains that in 1986 there was no fiscal impact statement, no floor debate, no funding of an increased benefit, and no indication in the title of the 1986 Appropriations Act that such an increase was intended.Â  Our reliance in Kennedy on evidence that the increased liability would render the Retirement System actuarially unsound was only one factor in determining legislative intent. 
8 Plaintiffsâ€™ experts were qualified in the sense their testimony was admissible.Â  I use the term â€œunqualifiedâ€ only to register the lack of credence I assign to their testimony.
9 The thirty-year liquidation period is a mandatory policy of the Board, not merely an aspirational goal.Â  The soundness of the System depends on continued compliance with the thirty-year liquidation period.Â  The System, through the Board, has been vigilant through the years to stay within the thirty-year liquidation period.Â  One example of these efforts is the accounting for a liability over a five-year period, known as â€œsmoothing.â€Â  This accounting adjustment began in approximately 1995 when the System was preparing to transition from book value to market related value.Â  â€œSmoothing,â€ which is a recognized approach, allows a retirement benefit/debt to be reflected pro rata over a five-year period, thereby avoiding significant fluctuations in a given year.Â  Plaintiffsâ€™ effort to assign nefarious motives to the â€œsmoothingâ€ method simply finds no traction in this record.
10 I do not suggest for a moment that the System, and those individuals charged with the fiduciary duty of managing the System, are beyond the reach of the courts.Â  Upon a proper showing, courts will provide appropriate relief.Â  Where, as here, there is an insufficient showing, the court should recognize, and defer to, the broad range of reasonableness inherent in determining acceptable actuarial applications and methodologies.
