THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Rock Hill Telephone Company, Inc.,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Globe Communications, Inc.,       
Defendant.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25952
Heard March 2, 2004 - Filed March 21, 2005Â Â Â 

CERTIFIED QUESTIONS ANSWERED


  
    
      
Robert A. McKenzie and Gary H. Johnson, II, both of McDonald, McKenzie, Rubin, Miller & Lybrand, of Columbia, for plaintiff.
Kenneth R. Raynor, of Templeton & Raynor, of Charlotte, for defendant.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Pursuant to Rule 228, SCACR, we accepted the following questions on certification from the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina:Â  

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Is the relationship between a utility holding a construction permit from the South Carolina Department of Transportation (DOT) and a subcontractor hired by the utilityâ€™s independent contractor a â€œspecial relationship,â€ allowing for a claim of equitable indemnity by the utility against the subcontractor?
II.       Does the utility have a nondelegable duty that makes it vicariously liable for the subcontractorâ€™s negligence?Â  

We answer both questions in the negative.Â Â Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
Rock Hill Telephone Company (utility) received a permit from the DOT to install an underground cable along a highway.Â  The utility hired an independent contractor to complete the work.Â  In turn, the independent contractor subcontracted a portion of the work to Globe Communications (subcontractor).Â Â Â  
One evening, a car struck the subcontractorâ€™s backhoe.Â  The driver of the car was severely injured, and she sued the utility and the subcontractor.[1]Â  The utility cross-claimed against the subcontractor on a theory of equitable indemnification.Â  After discovery and mediation, the utility settled with the driver for $300,000 and dismissed its indemnity action against the subcontractor without prejudice.Â  The subcontractor eventually settled with the driver for $1,500,000.Â  
The utility then sued the subcontractorâ€”the action currently pending in federal courtâ€”based on a theory of equitable indemnification, seeking to recover the $300,000 paid to the driver in settlement.Â Â Â Â  
Law/Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Special Relationship
The utility argues that it has a â€œspecial relationshipâ€ with the subcontractor supporting a claim for equitable indemnification.Â  We disagree.
There are two forms of indemnity: contractual indemnity and indemnity implied in law, or â€œequitable indemnity.â€Â  James C. Gray, Jr. and Lisa D. Catt, The Law of Indemnity in South Carolina, 41 S.C. L. Rev. 603, 604 (1990).Â  Contractual indemnity involves a transfer of risk for consideration, and the contract itself establishes the relationship between the parties.Â  Id.Â  Equitable indemnity, on the other hand, â€œis based upon the specific relation of the indemnitee to the indemnitor in dealing with a third party.â€Â  Id.Â  
In general, indemnity may be defined as a â€œform of compensation in which a first party is liable to pay a second party for a loss or damage the second party incurs to a third party.â€ First Gen. Servs. of Charleston, Inc. v. Miller, 314 S.C. 439, 442, 445 S.E.2d 446, 449 (1994) (quoting Town of Winnsboro v. Wiedemen-Singleton, Inc., 303 S.C. 52, 398 S.E.2d 500 (Ct. App. 1990), affâ€™d, 307 S.C. 128, 414 S.E.2d 118 (1992)).Â  The right to indemnity arises by operation of law â€œin cases of imputed fault or where some special relationship exists between the first and second parties.â€Â  Id.Â 
In other words, 

a right of indemnity exists whenever the relation between the parties is such that either in law or in equity there is an obligation on one party to indemnify the other, as where one person is exposed to liability by the wrongful act of another in which he does not join.[2]

Stuck v. Pioneer Logging Mach., Inc., 279 S.C. 22, 24, 301 S.E.2d 552, 553 (1983) (citations omitted).Â  We have held that the relationship between a contractor and a subcontractor supports a claim for equitable indemnification. First Gen. Servs., 314 S.C. at 442, 445 S.E.2d at 448; Town of Winnsboro, 307 S.C. at 131, 414 S.E.2d at 120.Â  
In the present case, however, the relationship between the utility and the subcontractor is an attenuated one.Â  The utility hired an independent contractor to install an underground communications line.Â  The contractor, in turn, hired a subcontractor to perform part of the work.Â  Given these facts, we find that the subcontractor is merely a remote or distant independent contractor, and therefore does not have a special relationship with the utility as contemplated under our jurisprudence.[3]Â Â  
Accordingly, the answer to the first certified question is no. 
II.       Vicarious Liability
The utility argues, in the alternative, that it has a nondelegable duty that makes it vicariously liable for the subcontractorâ€™s negligence.Â  We disagree.Â  
The general rule is that an employer is not vicariously liable for the negligent acts of an independent contractor.Â  Duane v. Presley Constr. Co., Inc., 270 S.C. 682, 683, 244 S.E.2d 509, 510 (1978).Â  An exception to the general rule is that â€œ[a] person who delegates to an independent contractor an absolute duty owed to another person remains liable for the negligence of the independent contractor just as if the independent contractor were an employee.â€Â  Durkin v. Hansen, 313 S.C. 343, 347, 437 S.E.2d 550, 552-53 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing 57 C.J.S. Master and Servant, Â§ 591 (1948)).Â  This Court has recently described the exceptionâ€”the nondelegable duty doctrineâ€”and its legal consequences, in the following way:

[a] person may delegate a duty to an independent contractor, but if the independent contractor breaches that duty by acting negligently or improperly, the delegating person remains liable for that breach.Â  It actually is the liability, not the duty, that is not delegable.Â  The party which owes the nondelegable duty is vicariously liable for negligent acts of the independent contractor.

Simmons v. Tuomey Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 341 S.C. 32, 42, 533 S.E.2d 312, 317 (2000).
Moreover, this Court has identified several situations in which the nondelegable duty doctrine applies:

An employer has a nondelegable duty to employees to provide a reasonably safe work place and suitable tools, and remains vicariously liable for injuries caused by unsafe activities or tools under the employerâ€™s control.
A landlord who undertakes repair of his property by use of a contractor has a nondelegable duty to see that the repair is done properly.
A common carrier has a nondelegable duty to ensure that cargo is properly loaded and secured, and remains vicariously liable for injuries caused by an unsecured load.
A bail bondsman has a nondelegable duty to supervise the work of his employees, and remains vicariously liable for injuries caused by those employees.
A municipality has a nondelegable duty to provide safe streets even when maintenance is undertaken by the state Highway Department, and remains vicariously liable for injuries caused by defective repairs.

Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 12, 550 S.E.2d 319, 323-24 (2001); see also Simmons, 341 S.C. at 50, 533 S.E.2d at 323 (holding that a hospital owes a nondelegable duty to render competent service to its emergency room patients).
In the present case, the utility contends that it had a nondelegable duty to perform the work in a safe manner.[4] Â Â This duty, the utility argues, stems from the language in the DOT permit and South Carolina statutory and regulatory law.[5]Â  The DOT permit provides, in relevant part, that the utility agrees â€œto assume any and all liability [the DOT] might otherwise have in connection with accidents or injuries to persons â€¦ [and] agrees to indemnify [the DOT] for any liability incurred.â€Â  In addition, statutory law provides that telephone companies may lay telephone lines if â€œsuch line is constructed so as not to endanger the safety of persons or interfere with the use of such highways or public roads.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-9-2020 (1976).Â  Finally, regulatory law provides that â€œ[e]ach utility shall exercise reasonable care to reduce the hazards to which its employees, its customers and the general public may be subjected.â€ 26 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 103-671 (1976) (emphasis added).
We hold that the provisions cited by the utility do not impose a nondelegable duty.Â  First, the terms in the permit are enforceable only as between the DOT and the utility, not the utility and a remote independent contractor.Â  Second, the statute and the regulation impose a duty of reasonable care, not an absolute, nondelegable duty.Â  
Therefore, because we find that the utility did not owe a nondelegable duty, the answer to the second certified question is no.
Conclusion
Because we find that (1) the relationship between the utility and a subcontractor hired by the utilityâ€™s independent contractor is not a â€œspecial relationship,â€ and that (2) the utility does not have a nondelegable duty making it vicariously liable for the subcontractorâ€™s negligence, we answer both certified questions in the negative.
MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and acting Justice Mark H. Westbrook, concur. PLEICONES, J, dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES: I write separately because I believe that Rock Hill is entitled to seek equitable indemnification from Globe, the negligent entity.Â  As explained below, I reach this conclusion by examining the facts presented to us.
The holder of a public franchise is subject to special liability rules, similar to those imposed upon common carriers.Â  The Restatement (2nd) of Torts Â§ 428 states the rule this way:

An individual or corporation carrying on an activity which can lawfully be carried on only under a franchise granted by a public authority and which involves an unreasonable risk of harm to others, is subject to liability for physical harm caused to others by the negligence of a contractor employed to do work in carrying on the activity.

The comments to this section make clear that the utility is liable to a person injured by the negligence of an independent contractor carrying on the exclusive business of that utility which involves an unreasonable risk of harm, but is not liable for the contractorâ€™s negligence in performing ordinary construction.Â  The critical question here, then, is whether Globe was doing unreasonably dangerous work that only the holder of a franchise could perform when Ms. Smith was injured.
The facts certified to us are that Ms. Smith was injured when she struck a tractor/backhoe belonging to Globe.Â  At the time of the accident, Globe was installing underground communications lines along a state highway pursuant to a permit issued to Rock Hill.Â  It is well established that the construction of transmission lines is an integral part of a utilityâ€™s business.Â  See e.g., Snyder v. Southern Calif. Edison Co., 44 Cal. 2d 793, 285 P.2d 912 (1955); compare, e.g. Reith v. General Tele. Co. of Illinois, 22 Ill. App. 3d 337, 317 N.E.2d 369 ( Ill. App. 5th Dist. 1974) (defendant utility has nondelegable duty to take safety precautions around excavation site constructed pursuant to franchise and state permit).Â  It is the utilityâ€™s nondelegable duty to insure that transmission lines are safely and properly installed, and it matters not whether the source of this duty is said to be the franchise agreement, statutes, or the common law.Â  Snyder, supra.Â Â Â Â  
The next question is whether equity will require the negligent party, Globe, to indemnify Rock Hill.Â  

[A] right to indemnity exists whenever the relationship between theÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â  parties is such that either in law or equity there is an obligation on one party to indemnify the other, as where one person is exposed to liability by the wrongful act of another in which he does not join.

Stuck v. Pioneer Logging Mach. Inc., 279 S.C. 22, 24, 301 S.E.2d 552, 553 (1983) (emphasis supplied).
Unlike the majority, I find the attenuated relationship between Rock Hill and Globe weighs in favor of equitable indemnification rather than against it.Â  Rock Hill employed an independent contractor, which in turn chose the negligent subcontractor.Â  The majority acknowledges that the independent contractor here would be entitled to indemnity, but denies that relief to Rock Hill, which had absolutely nothing to do with the selection of Globe.Â  
In my opinion, since Rock Hill did not join in Globeâ€™s negligent act, but is liable as the result of its franchise and its DOT permit, I would find Rock Hill entitled to equitable indemnity.

[1] It is unclear as to why the driver did not also sue the independent contractor hired by the utility.
[2] In general, there is no right to indemnity between joint tortfeasors.Â  Atl. Coast Line R.R. Co. v. Whetstone, 243 S.C. 61, 70, 132 S.E.2d 172, 176 (1963).Â  In the underlying case, both Rock Hill and Globe settled with the driver before liability could be determined.Â  Because there is no evidence in the record that Rock Hill was adjudged to be without fault, we are unwilling to recognize a right of indemnity on this basis as well.Â  See Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 63, 518 S.E.2d 301, 307 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding that the most important requirement for the finding of equitable indemnity is that the party seeking to be indemnified is adjudged without fault and the indemnifying party is the one at fault).Â  
[3] Unlike the dissent, we find that there must be some kind of relationship between the parties beyond the relationship established by virtue of one party alleging that he was sued because of another partyâ€™s wrongdoing.Â  See, e.g, First Gen. Serv., 314 S.C. at 443, 445 S.E.2d at 448 (holding relationship between contractor and subcontractor supports a claim of equitable indemnification); Stuck, 279 S.C. at 24, 301 S.E.2d at 553 (holding purchaser of defective vehicle was entitled to indemnification from seller); Addy v. Bolton, 257 S.C. 28, 33, 183 S.E.2d 708, 709 (1971) (holding landlord entitled to indemnification from general contractor for damage caused to tenantâ€™s property).Â  Â Â 
[4] Although this argument seems counterintuitive, it is necessary for the utility to establish that it would have initially been liable for the subcontractorâ€™s negligence.Â  See First Gen. Servs., 314 S.C. at 442, 445 S.E.2d at 449 (the right to indemnity arises by operation of law â€œin cases of imputed fault or where some special relationship exists between the first and second partiesâ€).
[5] We respectfully find the dissentâ€™s analysis of this issue rests on facts that are not part of the record.Â  Therefore, we analyze this issue based solely on the language in the DOT permit and the statutory law identified by Rock Hill as the source of its alleged nondelegable duty.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Cecil Heyward Dempsey,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,        Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Orangeburg County
Donald W. Beatty, Trial Judge
Rodney A. Peeples, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Opinion No. 25954
Submitted October 20, 2004 - Filed March 21, 2005Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Chief, Capital & Collateral Litigation Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Elizabeth R. McMahon, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Respondent.
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Respondent Cecil Heyward Dempsey (Dempsey) was convicted of first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and was sentenced to thirty years in prison.Â  The court of appeals affirmed.Â  State v. Dempsey, 340 S.C. 365, 532 S.E.2d 306 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Dempsey applied for post conviction relief (PCR) and relief was granted.Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari.Â  We reverse.
Factual/Procedural Background
Dempsey was charged with CSC with a minor for sexually abusing his nine-year-old stepson (victim).Â  The victim testified that Dempsey sexually abused him â€œfour times [a week], almost everydayâ€ for a period of more than a year.Â  In addition, the Stateâ€™s case included testimony of the arresting officer and several doctors and counselors at the Low Country Childrenâ€™s Center, a center that specializes in caring for abused children.
The State offers the following issues for review:Â  

  
    Did the PCR court err when it found Dempseyâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to subpoena the victimâ€™s grandfather to offer testimony that could have potentially exculpated Dempsey?
    
  
    Did the PCR court err when it found Dempseyâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to offer expert testimony on sexual abuse to rebut the stateâ€™s expert testimony?
    
  
    Did the PCR court err when it found Dempseyâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to request a jury charge of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN)?

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
This Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law. Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (citing McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995)).Â  On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any evidence of probative value sufficient to support them. Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).Â  If no probative evidence exists to support the findings, the Court will reverse. Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000) (citing Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996)).
First, to be entitled to PCR, the applicant must show that counselâ€™s performance was deficient.Â  Payne v. State, 355 S.C. 642, 645, 586 S.E.2d 857, 859 (2003) (citing Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 688, 694 (1984)).Â  An attorneyâ€™s performance is not deficient if it is reasonable under professional norms. Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 117, 386 S.E.2d 624, 625 (1989).Â  Second, the applicant must show that there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s deficiency, the result of the proceeding would have been different.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694.Â  
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Failure to Subpoena Witness
The State argues that the PCR judge erred in granting Dempsey relief on the basis that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to subpoena an out-of-state witness that would have allegedly offered exculpatory testimony.Â  We agree.
A PCR applicant cannot show that he was prejudiced by counselâ€™s failure to call a favorable witness to testify at trial if that witness does not later testify at the PCR hearing or otherwise offer testimony within the rules of evidence.Â  Glover v. State, 318 S.C. 496, 498, 458 S.E.2d 538, 540 (1995). 
In his PCR application, Dempsey claimed trial counsel was ineffective for failing to subpoena the victimâ€™s grandfather, who Dempsey alleged would have testified that the victim lied about being sexually assaulted.Â  At the PCR hearing, counsel admitted that he did not know the proper procedure to subpoena an out-of-state witness.Â  Nevertheless, because we cannot determine what the victimâ€™s grandfather would have said in his testimony, any prejudice to Dempsey is merely speculative.Â  In addition, because the victimâ€™s grandfather did not testify at the PCR hearing or otherwise have his testimony offered, there is no evidence that, if counsel had subpoenaed the witness, the result at trial would have been different.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the PCR court erred in granting relief on the basis that trial counsel was ineffective in failing to subpoena the victimâ€™s grandfather to testify at trial.
II.              
Failure to Present Expert Testimony 
The State argues that the PCR judge erred in granting Dempsey relief on the basis that counsel was ineffective for failing to offer expert testimony on child sexual abuse to rebut the testimony of the stateâ€™s expert witness.Â  We agree.
At trial, the State called Dr. Donald Elsey, a therapist at the Low Country Childrenâ€™s Center, to testify as an expert on child sexual abuse.Â  Dr. Elsey testified that it was his opinion that the victim had been sexually abused.Â  
In addition, the State presented expert testimony from Dr. Elizabeth Baker who performed the victimâ€™s physical examination.Â  Dr. Baker testified that she found no physical evidence that the victim was sexually abused, but that it was likely that if someone was assaulted in the manner in which the victim alleged, there would be no physical evidence of the assault.Â  Dempseyâ€™s counsel did not call an expert to rebut the Stateâ€™s expert testimony because he believed that the lack of physical evidence of abuse, by itself, was enough to rebut the stateâ€™s expert testimony.
First, because Dempsey failed to have an expert on child sexual abuse testify at the PCR hearing, we hold that any finding of prejudice is merely speculative.Â Â Â  Second, we find that counselâ€™s decision not to call an expert witness to rebut the stateâ€™s expert witness was a legitimate trial strategy.Â  See McLaughlin v. State, 352 S.C. 476, 483-484, 575 S.E.2d 841, 844-845 (2003) (holding that where counsel articulates a valid reason for employing a certain trial strategy, such conduct will not be deemed ineffective assistance of counsel.) Accordingly, we hold that the PCR court erred in granting relief on the basis that trial counsel was ineffective in failing to call an expert witness on child sexual abuse.
III.          
Failure to Request Jury Charge 
The State argues that the PCR judge erred in granting relief on the basis that counsel was ineffective for failing to request a jury charge on the lesser-included offense of ABHAN.Â  We agree.
A judge must charge the jury on material issues raised by the evidence. Frasier v. State, 306 S.C. 158, 162, 410 S.E.2d 572, 574 (1991).Â  Nevertheless, a judge is required to charge a jury on a lesser-included offense â€œif there is any evidence from which it could be inferred the lesser, rather than the greater, offense was committed.â€Â  State v. Gourdine, 322 S.C. 396, 398, 472 S.E.2d 241, 242 (1996) (emphasis supplied).
ABHAN is a lesser-included charge of CSC. State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 582, 564 S.E.2d 103, 106 (2002).Â  ABHAN is the unlawful act of violent injury to another accompanied by circumstances of aggravation. Id. at 580, 564 S.E.2d at 105.Â  Circumstances of aggravation include the use of a deadly weapon, intent to commit a felony, infliction of serious bodily injury, great disparity in the ages or physical conditions of the parties, a difference in gender, the purposeful infliction of shame and disgrace, taking indecent liberties of familiarities with a female, and resistance to lawful authority.Â  Id. at 580-581, 564 S.E.2d at 105-106.
In the present case, both the victimâ€™s aunt and the victim testified that Dempsey acted violently towards the victim.Â  The aunt testified that on one occasion she witnessed Dempsey pick up the victim and yell obscenities at him.Â  In addition, victim testified that on another occasion Dempsey â€œjacked [the victim] up against the wallâ€ and threatened to hurt him if he told anyone about the sexual abuse.Â  Nevertheless, the evidence indicates that on several different occasions Dempsey forced the victim to perform various sexual acts.Â  We find that there is no evidence that Dempsey committed ABHAN rather than CSC with a minor on those occasions.
In this case, Dempsey points to evidence that he physically assaulted the victim to support his claim that counsel was ineffective in failing to request an ABHAN charge.Â  The indictment charged that the CSC occurred between December 1996 and June 1997, during which period there was evidence of several instances of sexual battery.Â  While it is true, as Dempsey contends, that there was also evidence of conduct that could be construed as ABHAN, none of these incidents was alleged to have occurred instead of the sexual batteries.Â  Under these circumstances, where there is no evidence from which it could be inferred that ABHAN rather than CSC was committed, an ABHAN charge is not warranted.
Conclusion
We find no evidence of probative value sufficient to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that counsel was ineffective.
REVERSED.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT AND PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gary James Long, Jr.,       
Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT
OF APPEALS

Appeal From Sumter County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25955
Heard February 15, 2005 - Filed March 21, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David I. Bruck, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to review a Court of Appealsâ€™ decision holding that, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2946 (Supp. 2004), a law enforcement officer may require, without first offering a breath test, a person charged with felony driving under the influence (Felony DUI)[1] to submit to a chemical test of his blood.Â  State v. Long, Op. No. 2003-UP-111 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 12, 2003).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Following a single-car accident, petitioner (Driver) and his two passengers were transported to a hospital.Â  One of the passengers died as a result of injuries received.Â  Around 4 a.m., several hours after Driver arrived at the hospital, a blood sample was taken at the behest of a law enforcement officer.
At trial, Driver objected to the introduction of the results of this blood test since he alleged he had neither been offered a breath test nor had a licensed medical personnel determined that he was unable to give a breath sample.Â  Driver relied upon the general implied consent statute,[2] which provides â€œthe person must first be offered a breath testâ€¦[unless] the person is physically unable to provide an acceptable breath sample because he has an injured mouth, is unconscious or dead, or for any other reason considered acceptable by the licensed medical personnelâ€¦.â€ before a blood sample may be taken. Â Â§ 56-5-2950(a).Â  The State contended, and the trial judge agreed, that the specific statute applicable to individuals suspected of Felony DUI, Â§ 56-5-2946, obviated the requirement of Â§ 56-5-2950(a) that a breath test be offered or be deemed unavailable, before a blood test is ordered.Â  The test result was admitted, and on appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed.
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err in holding that
Â§ 56-5-2946 altered the prerequisites for ordering a blood test of individuals charged with Felony DUI?

ANALYSIS
The general implied consent statute was rewritten by 1998 Act No. 434, Â§ 7.Â  Section 6 of that same act created Â§ 56-5-2946.Â  We are not asked today to determine all the changes wrought by Â§ 56-5-2946, but only whether this statute alters the general requirement that an officer offer a breath test or obtain a medical opinion that such a test is not feasible before offering a blood test.Â  We hold that it does.
Pursuant to Â§ 56-5-2950, a person driving a motor vehicle in South Carolina is deemed to have consented to a chemical test of his breath, blood, or urine if arrested for an offense arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or a combination of the two.Â  Â§ 56-5-2950(a).Â  The arresting officer must first assure the individual is offered a breath test, unless â€œlicensed medical personnelâ€ deems such a test unacceptable.Â  In that case, the officer may request a blood test.Â  Id.Â  The officer must notify the individual of his right to independent testing, and provide affirmative assistance to assist in arranging such testing.Â  Id. 
Section 56-5-2950(a) also prescribes certain technical testing requirements, such as requiring an accurate simulator test be performed before the breath test is administered, and that blood and urine samples be obtained by medical personnel.Â  This section also provides civil and criminal immunity to those administering the tests or obtaining the samples in most situations. 
Part (b) of Â§ 56-5-2950 provides for certain evidentiary presumptions based upon the alcohol concentrations shown by the tests.Â  Part (c) deems an unconscious person or one otherwise unable to refuse to have been informed as provided by part (a).Â  Part (d) requires the individual be given a written report giving the times and results of tests, and requires him to furnish results of his independent test to the arresting officer if the driver intends to rely upon that test result as evidence.Â  Part (e) provides for judicial or administrative review of regulations, and for the exclusion of evidence if these regulations are not complied with, and part (f) permits fees to be assessed for certain services.
Section 56-5-2946 is entitled â€œSubmission to testing for alcohol or drugs,â€ and applies only to persons believed to have committed Felony DUI.Â  This statute begins with â€œNotwithstanding any other provision of law, a person must submitâ€ to chemical tests to determine alcohol concentration when he is suspected of Felony DUI.Â  The second paragraph of Â§ 56-5-2946 provides, â€œThe tests must be administered at the direction of a law enforcement officerâ€¦A person who is tested or gives samples must be notified of his right to independent tests.â€
These two paragraphs essentially alter the procedural prerequisites which must be met under Â§ 56-5-2950 before an officer may order a blood test for a Felony DUI suspect.Â  Under Â§ 56-5-2946, the officer need no longer offer a breath test as the first option, nor must he obtain a medical opinion that such a test is not feasible before ordering a test or sample.Â  
Driver contends that Â§ 56-5-2946 retains all the requirements of Â§ 56-5-2950.Â  This contention is based upon Â§ 56-5-2946â€™s third paragraph, which provides:

The provisions of Section 56-5-2950, relating to the administration of tests to determine a personâ€™s alcohol concentration, additional tests at the personâ€™s expense, the availability of other evidence on the question of whether or not the person was under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or a combination of them, availability of test information to the person or his attorney, and the liability of medical institutions and persons administering the tests are applicable to this section and also extend to the officer requesting the test, the State or its political subdivisions, or governmental agency, or entity which employs the officer making the request, and the agency, institution, or employer, either governmental or private, of persons administering the tests.Â  Notwithstanding any other provision of state law pertaining to confidentiality of hospital records or other medical records, information regarding tests performed pursuant to this section must be released, upon subpoena, to a court, prosecuting attorney, defense attorney, or law enforcement officer in connection with an alleged violation of Section 56-5-2945.

We disagree with Driverâ€™s interpretation of this paragraph.Â  The legislature is presumed to intend that its statutes accomplish something.Â  E.g., S.C. Coastal Conserv. League v. S.C. DHEC, 354 S.C. 585, 582 S.E.2d 410 (2003).Â  Driverâ€™s reading of the statute, to duplicate the requirements of Â§ 56-5-2950, renders Â§ 56-5-2946 virtually meaningless.Â  Driverâ€™s construction violates the rule that a statute is presumed to have meaning, and ignores the language of the statute itself.
We hold that paragraph three of Â§ 56-5-2946 incorporates the technical testing requirements of Â§ 56-5-2950(a).Â  The paragraph also makes clear that the release from liability provisions of Â§ 56-5-2950(a) apply to persons acting pursuant to Â§ 56-5-2946, incorporates other informational requirements of Â§ 56-5-2950(d), and provides for the applicability of the evidentiary rules found in Â§ 56-5-2950(b) and (e).Â  The Court of Appeals was correct in affirming the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the officer was not required to offer a breath test or receive a medical opinion before ordering Driverâ€™s blood test.
CONCLUSION
A law enforcement officer can order a person suspected of Felony DUI to submit to any chemical test without first offering a breath test.Â  The decision of the Court of Appeals is 
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, CJ., MOORE, WALLER AND BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2945 (Supp. 2004).
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2004).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25956
Heard February 3, 2005 - Filed March 21, 2005

INDEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster and Senior Assistant Attorney General James G. Bogle, Jr., both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, the Commission on Lawyer Conduct filed formal charges against respondent, Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr.Â  After a hearing, the Panel recommended an indefinite suspension.
FACTUAL BACKGROUND
The charges against respondent stem from his involvement in a real estate deal with two doctors.Â  The Doctors and respondent formed a limited liability company (LLC) for the purpose of purchasing a lot and constructing a building in which respondent could rent law office space.Â  The agreement was for the Doctors to provide the purchase money and then become â€œsilent partnersâ€ with respondent.Â  Respondentâ€™s duties, as the Doctors understood them, were to:Â  (1) handle all architectural fees at no cost to the Doctors; (2) perform all of the legal work involved at no cost;[1] (3) use his contacts in the area with a contractor to construct the building and supervise all construction; and (4) lease the building from the LLC at a fair market value, with plans for the Doctors to get their initial investment back in seven years, and thereafter the LLC would turn a profit for all members.
An attorney, other than respondent, closed a $300,000 construction loan from Anchor Bank on March 24, 1998.Â  Subsequently, respondent opened the LLC account with Anchor Bank.Â  On the day the LLC account was opened, respondent wrote a check, payable to himself, labeled â€œcosts/expensesâ€ in the amount of $15,000, and then deposited the check into his personal bank account.Â  This check was the beginning of many LLC checks that respondent would write to himself or his law firm.Â  Respondent did not inform the Doctors he was going to write checks from the LLC account to himself and his firm, nor that he would do so in order to pay vendors out of his personal or law firm accounts.
The allegations of misconduct against respondent in the Formal Charges cover four areas:Â  (1) that respondent engaged in a scheme to misappropriate funds from the LLC; (2) that respondent drafted or participated in the last-minute submission of a settlement agreement, between he and the Doctors, that contained elements inconsistent with settlement agreements he had already signed or put on the record before the circuit court; (3) that respondent participated in or authorized frivolous litigation; and (4) that respondent failed to cooperate with the disciplinary investigation. We separate the allegations into these four categories:Â  The LLC, Misappropriation of Funds, The Litigation, and Failure to Cooperate.
The LLC
A few months after the LLC closed on the construction loan at Anchor Bank, respondent convinced the Doctors to refinance the loan for $360,000 at another bank.Â  Respondent assured the Doctors the extra $60,000 would never actually be needed and that he would pay the entire amount back.Â  An attorney, other than the previous closing attorney and respondent, conducted the closing for the refinancing.
Subsequently, respondent met with the Doctors and informed them that, although he had paid the contractor for the building being constructed, the contractor had not paid two vendors who then filed mechanicâ€™s liens as a result.Â  One of the Doctors testified respondent stated the Doctors needed to place more money in the LLC account to pay the liens in order to avoid a bad credit rating.Â  Respondent explained that the vendors who filed the liens had a legal right to do so; however, the Doctors believed this advice was incorrect.Â  The Panel found respondent had given false legal advice to his clients.
In September 1998, the Doctors requested the LLC records from respondent so that they could examine them.Â  After repeated delays by respondent, the Doctors contacted respondent who stated he had taken all the records to Greg Lipe, an accountant.Â  Respondent had not in fact taken any records to Lipe at this time.Â  The Doctorsâ€™ accountant, Lawrence D. Guerry, finally retrieved the records directly from the bank.
When the Doctors examined the bank records, they were disturbed because respondent had written LLC checks to himself, his law firm, to his wife in one incident, and because the account had been subject to several insufficient funds fees and other bank fees indicating a mismanagement of the account by respondent.Â  The Doctors also discovered that at least three LLC checks and possibly more, totaling over $13,800, had been written to the respondentâ€™s law firm for legal fees.Â  The Doctors never received a bill or an accounting from respondent has to how he had earned the alleged legal fees.
When a settlement could not be reached between the Doctors and respondent with the assistance of their respective attorneys, the Doctors filed a suit against respondent and his firm in July 1999.Â  At the end of July, the attorneys placed a settlement agreement on the record in front of a circuit court judge that provided respondent would purchase the Doctorsâ€™ interest in the LLC for $148,000.Â  The closing did not occur as planned and respondent requested an extension of time.
A closing was eventually set for October 6, 1999.Â  However it did not occur because, on the morning of the closing date, respondentâ€™s attorney, Craig Young, faxed a Severance Agreement to the Doctorsâ€™ attorney, Jerome Askins.Â  This agreement contained items that were not agreed upon.Â  The details of this incident are discussed below under the heading, â€œThe Litigation.â€
After a motion to compel settlement and other negotiations, the litigation was eventually settled and the building was sold.Â  As part of the settlement, respondent paid the Doctors the amount of their net loss from the venture.Â  Therefore, the Doctors recovered the money they had lost.
The Panel found that, while respondent contended he was simply a business partner with the Doctors in this venture and did not perform legal services on their behalf, the facts showed otherwise given that respondent acted as an attorney for the LLC regarding the mechanicâ€™s liens and given that he had written LLC checks, with the label â€œlegalâ€ or â€œlegal feesâ€ to his law firm.
Misappropriation of Funds
Respondent admits he did not maintain detailed records of the transactions involving the LLC account and that he is unable to provide an accounting of the funds that were deposited into the LLC account or to trace the funds into and out of the account.Â  The Panel found it was clear respondent was writing checks back and forth from his two law firm accounts (one at Anchor Bank and one at Carolina First Bank), his personal account, and the LLC account.Â  The Panel stated respondent was expending sums from all of these accounts for items totally unrelated to the building being constructed by the LLC.Â  The Panel found respondent often had negative balances in his personal and law firm accounts.
Although there were numerous instances of check writing misconduct, for brevity we cite only two examples:

(1)     Respondent wrote LLC check number 115, in the amount of $5,000 to himself, and deposited it into his personal account at Anchor Bank on the same day.Â  The balance in his personal account had been negative (-) $211.95 three days earlier.Â  On the date of the deposit of the LLC check, respondentâ€™s personal account balance rose to $3,924.06.
(2)     Respondent wrote LLC check number 143, to â€œThomas E. Ruffin, Jr., P.C.,â€ in the amount of $5,550.Â  A deposit was made into the law firm general account (at Carolina First Bank) of $5,500 on July 8 and $50 on July 9.Â  On July 8, the balance in the law firm account rose to negative (-) $955.13 but dropped to negative (-) $5,005.13 on July 9.Â  It rose to $1,494.87 on July 13, 1998, aided by a deposit of $6,500 on that day.Â  That rise was a result of the deposit of LLC check number 151, in the amount of $6,500, written to â€œRuffin Law Firm - General Account.â€Â  That month, there were nine insufficient funds fees on respondentâ€™s law firm account at Carolina First Bank.

Respondentâ€™s accountant, after analyzing the cost of the construction project and respondentâ€™s transfer of funds from the LLC account to respondentâ€™s law firm accounts or personal account, determined that the total amount due appeared to be $30,390.70.Â  The Attorney to Assist (ATA), who was appointed to investigate this matter, concluded there was a total shortage of $30,023.45.[2]Â  The Doctorsâ€™ accountant, Lawrence D. Guerry, testified it was disturbing that respondentâ€™s LLC checks were almost always in round figures, which, he testified, is atypical of checks written to vendors in a construction project.
The Litigation
The Doctorsâ€™ attorney, Jerome Askins, III, (Askins) testified that, in the beginning of his representation of the Doctors, he made several unsuccessful attempts to meet with respondent to discuss the LLC bank records.Â  Once a meeting was held, it became apparent respondent had engaged in financial misconduct in relation to the LLC account.Â  Askins filed suit on behalf of the Doctors when negotiations with respondent to buy the building were unsuccessful.Â  The matter was finally scheduled for a settlement and closing on October 6, 1999.Â  On that date, Askins received a fax, which changed the previous agreement.Â  He testified this new agreement, known as the Severance Agreement, was not a part of the settlement that had previously been placed on the record.
Paragraph 5 of the agreement stated that respondent had never served as an attorney for the Doctors or the LLC; however, respondent had in fact represented the LLC in mechanicâ€™s lien actions. 
Paragraph 6 of the agreement faxed by respondentâ€™s attorney, Young, was a confidentiality clause and a statement of the penalty upon the Doctors if the confidentiality should be breached.[3]
Thereafter, Young filed a Counterclaim and Third Party Complaint involving RICO violations.[4]Â  As a result, Askins had to withdraw from representing the Doctors and the Doctors had to find new counsel.Â  Subsequently, the circuit court issued an order, which noted the third party action against Askins had been ended by the payment of $10,000 to Askins from respondent.
Failure to Cooperate
The Commission requested that respondent deliver certain bank records to the investigator.Â  Respondent only partially complied with the request.Â  He failed to provide all of the bank statements, cancelled checks, and deposit slips that were requested.Â  Respondent admits that, due to poor record-keeping, he is unable to provide all of the requested financial information.
Panelâ€™s Findings
The Panel found the following violations of Rule 7(a) of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  7(a)(1), violating a Rule of Professional Conduct; 7(a)(3), failing to fully comply with a subpoena issued by the Commission; 7(a)(5), engaging in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law; and 7(a)(6), violating the oath of office taken upon admission to practice law in this State.
The Panel further found respondent violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The Panel found violations of Rule 1.1, competence; Rule 1.2, scope of representation; Rule 1.5, fees; Rule 1.7, conflict of interest; Rule 1.15, safekeeping property; Rule 3.1, meritorious claims and contentions; Rule 3.3, candor toward a tribunal; Rule 3.4, fairness to opposing party and counsel; Rule 4.1, truthfulness in statements to others; Rule 8.1(b), failure to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority; Rule 8.4(a), violating the Rules of Professional Conduct; Rule 8.4(c), engaging in conduct involving moral turpitude; Rule 8.4(d), engaging in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation; and Rule 8.4(e) engaging in conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice.[5]
The Panel found respondentâ€™s misconduct was mitigated by the eventual settlement and the fact that respondent did not have a prior disciplinary record.Â  The Panel concluded the appropriate sanction was an indefinite suspension and a requirement that respondent pay the costs of the proceedings.Â  Both Disciplinary Counsel and respondent have raised issues regarding the Panelâ€™s report.
ISSUES

  
    Did the Panel err by failing to find respondent had engaged in check kiting?
    
  
    Did the Panel err by failing to find respondent had filed a third party RICO action without a sufficient factual basis?
    
  
    Did the Panel err by finding respondent violated certain rules of the Rules for Professional Conduct?

DISCUSSION
I
Disciplinary Counsel argues the Panel erred by failing to find respondent had violated Rule 8.4(b) of the Rules for Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, by engaging in check kiting.Â  Rule 8.4(b) defines attorney misconduct to include committing a criminal act that reflects adversely on a lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer in other respects.
We find the Panel did not err by failing to find a violation of Rule 8.4(b) because there was no evidence of check kiting.Â  Check kiting involves creating artificial balances in an account until funds are received to cover shortages in that account.Â  While respondent wrote checks from the LLC account presumably to cover his personal and law firm accounts that had insufficient funds to cover checks he had written from those accounts, there is no evidence respondent was engaged in an intentional scheme to kite checks.Â  Cf. In re Miller, 328 S.C. 283, 494 S.E.2d 120 (1997) (disbarment administered for soliciting assistance of other persons to engage in check kiting); In re Robson, 318 S.C. 77, 456 S.E.2d 374 (1995) (disbarment administered for entering guilty plea to check kiting); In re Gibbes, 323 S.C. 80, 450 S.E.2d 588 (1994) (disbarment administered for devising and implementing check kiting scheme).Â  Further, there is no evidence respondent was â€œknowingly covering checks drawn on insufficient funds with worthless checks deposited from other accounts and taking advantage of the lag time necessary for clearance of the checks to keep the â€˜kiteâ€™ afloat.â€Â  In re Gates, 311 S.C. 246, 247, 428 S.E.2d 716, 717 (1993) (emphasis added).Â  The LLC checks respondent used to eliminate negative balances in his personal and law firm accounts were not worthless.
Accordingly, the Panel did not err by failing to find respondent had violated Rule 8.4(b) because there is no evidence respondent engaged in check kiting.Â  See In re Flom, 356 S.C. 246, 588 S.E.2d 593 (2003) (disciplinary violation must be proven by clear and convincing evidence).
II
Disciplinary counsel argues the Panel erred by failing to find respondent had, through his counsel, frivolously filed a third party RICO complaint against the Doctorsâ€™ attorney, Jerome Askins.Â  Specifically, Disciplinary Counsel argues the Panel erred by failing to find respondent had violated Rule 3.1, meritorious claims and contentions; Rule 3.3, candor to a tribunal; Rule 3.4, fairness to opposing party and counsel; and Rule 8.4 (misconduct), subsections (a), (d), and (e).Â  However, the Panel in fact found respondent had violated all of those rules and that he had frivolously filed the RICO complaint.Â  Therefore, Disciplinary Counselâ€™s argument is without merit.
However, we disagree with the Panelâ€™s finding that respondent frivolously filed the RICO complaint because there is not clear and convincing evidence of this misconduct.Â  See In re Flom, supra (disciplinary violation must be proven by clear and convincing evidence).Â  Respondent testified he relied on the advice of his attorney because the area of RICO law was not within his area of expertise.Â  Therefore, the Panel erred by finding respondent violated Rule 3.1, which states a lawyer shall not bring or defend a proceeding, unless there is a basis for doing so that is not frivolous.
III
Respondent argues the Panel erred by finding he had violated certain Professional Rules.Â  We agree with respondent in part.
Initially, we disagree with the Panelâ€™s finding that a legal relationship, outside of the mechanicâ€™s lien actions, existed between respondent and the Doctors.Â  There is a dispute in the testimony as to whether a legal relationship existed.Â  The Doctors testified respondent was to act as their attorney and the LLCâ€™s attorney by preparing documents related to the LLC and by performing the closings on the real estate and the loan refinancing.Â  Respondent testified he never informed the Doctors that he would be performing legal work and that he told the Doctors that he would be able to get legal work done by another attorney for a reduced rate.Â  Consistent with respondentâ€™s testimony, the real estate and refinancing closings were performed by other attorneys.Â  Further, another attorney assisted in the preparation of the LLC documents.
While the Panel finds a legal relationship existed partially on the basis that checks, denoted â€œlegalâ€ or â€œlegal fees,â€ from the LLC account were made out to respondent or his law firm, we do not find this fact dispositive.Â  It is clear that attorneys, other than respondent, handled the legal issues that arose with the LLC.Â  Therefore, it appears respondent may have used these particular checks to take money from the LLC account for a seemingly proper reason.
Given we may make our own findings of fact and conclusions of law in a disciplinary action, we find respondent did not have a general legal relationship with the Doctors and the LLC.Â  In re Wilkes, 359 S.C. 540, 598 S.E.2d 272 (2004) (Court may make own findings of fact and conclusions of law in disciplinary action).Â  The allegation that respondentâ€™s misconduct arose out of the existence of a legal relationship was not proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  See In re Flom, supra (disciplinary violation must be proven by clear and convincing evidence).
Because we find a general legal relationship did not exist between respondents and the Doctors or the LLC, we find the Panel erred by finding respondent violated Rule 1.2 (scope of representation), Rule 1.7 (conflict of interest), and Rule 1.15 (safekeeping property).
Respondent argues the Panel erred by finding he had violated Rule 7(a)(5), Rule 1.1, Rule 3.3., Rule 3.4, and Rule 4.1.Â  We uphold the Panelâ€™s findings that respondent violated Rule 7(a)(5), Rule 3.3, and Rule 3.4 without comment.
Regarding Rule 1.1. (competence), we find the Panel did not err by finding a Rule 1.1 violation because respondent incorrectly advised the Doctors regarding mechanicâ€™s liens actions that had been filed against the LLC.Â  Regarding respondentâ€™s misstatements to the Doctors, the Panel also found respondent had violated Rule 4.1, which provides:Â  â€œIn the course of representing a client a lawyer shall not knowingly:Â  (a) Make a false statement of material fact or law to a third person . . . .â€Â  Whether respondentâ€™s advice was simply due to incompetence or due to respondentâ€™s desire to acquire more money from the Doctors is unclear.Â  Because there is not clear and convincing evidence that respondent violated Rule 4.1, we find the Panel erred by finding respondent violated this rule.Â  See In re Flom, supra (disciplinary violation must be proven by clear and convincing evidence).
SANCTION
This Court has the sole authority to discipline attorneys and to decide the appropriate sanction after a thorough review of the record.Â  In re Thompson, 343 S.C. 1, 539 S.E.2d 396 (2000).Â  The Court may make its own findings of fact and conclusions of law, and is not bound by the Panelâ€™s recommendation.Â  In re Larkin, 336 S.C. 366, 520 S.E.2d 804 (1999).Â  The Court must administer the sanction it deems appropriate after a thorough review of the record.Â  Id.
We have deemed indefinite suspension the appropriate sanction in similar cases.Â  See In re Perrow, 346 S.C. 515, 552 S.E.2d 295 (2001) (indefinite suspension where attorney issued check to himself that exceeded his fee in several cases and used funds in escrow account to pay for repairs to residence); In re Jenkins, 346 S.C. 617, 552 S.E.2d 734 (2001) (indefinite suspension where attorney failed to respond to disciplinary authority and thereby admitted misconduct of failing to pay bar license fees, failing to comply with CLE requirements, and failing to appear as ordered by the Court).Â  See also In re Sipes, 297 S.C. 531, 377 S.E.2d 574 (1989) (although practice of law not involved, Court ordered one-year suspension for attorneyâ€™s misappropriation of Girl Scout cookie funds and attempt to repay funds through forged checks drawn on a closed account).
We indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law and order him to pay the costs of the disciplinary proceedings.Â  If he has not already done so, within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall surrender his certificate of admission to practice law in this state to the Clerk of Court and shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
INDEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. 

[1]Respondent testified he was not acting as an attorney for the LLC, except for two mechanicâ€™s lien actions that arose later; and that he simply promised the Doctors he would be able to have any legal matters regarding the LLC completed at a reduced rate by other attorneys. 
[2]A circuit court order noted that it had been determined by accountants that there was $34,904.90 in LLC funds that could not be accounted for by respondent.
[3]During respondentâ€™s attorneyâ€™s testimony, it became clear that respondentâ€™s attorney, Craig Young, and not respondent, had inserted the offending paragraphs into the agreement.
[4]A RICO violation is a violation of the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act.Â  Racketeering involves a person who uses extortion, loan sharking, bribery, or obstruction of justice to further his illegal activities.Â  Usually this person uses some sort of authority or power to illegally persuade others to further his interests.
Mr. Young explained he filed the third party complaint against Askins with a clear understanding of RICO violations.Â  Young testified he filed the third party complaint as a result of Askins calling him and stating that Young would get his client to do what the Doctors wanted regarding the settlement or that Askins was going to get the solicitorâ€™s office and SLED involved.Â  Respondent asserts he relied on Youngâ€™s expertise in determining whether to file the RICO action.
[5]Regarding Rule 8.4, the Panel incorrectly lettered the subsections of the rule.Â  The correct rules are noted above.

title: Leamon v. State
description: In this case, the Court held the statute of limitations for PCR applications, S.C. Code  Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003), applies to an applicant who is incarcerated in another jurisdiction.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Robert Lee Leamon, Petitioner
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF
CERTIORARI


Appeal From Greenville County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Trial Judge
Â John W. Kittredge, Post-Conviction Judge

Opinion No. 25957
Submitted February 16, 2005 - Filed March 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Henry Dargan McMaster, John W. McIntosh, Salley W. Elliott, and Elizabeth R. McMahon, all of the Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Robert Lee Leamon (Petitioner) pled guilty to five counts of armed robbery and was sentenced to concurrent terms of imprisonment for twenty-five years on each count.Â  The post-conviction relief (PCR) judge concluded Petitionerâ€™s PCR application was time-barred.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner was jailed in North Carolina on December 6, 1992.Â Â Â  On December 9, 1992, South Carolina placed a detainer on Petitioner.Â  In October 1995, Petitioner was indicted by the Greenville County Grand Jury for five counts of armed robbery.Â  Petitioner was transported to South Carolina and on November 20, 1995, he pled guilty to those charges.Â  After pleading guilty, Petitioner was returned to North Carolina to serve his remaining sentence for crimes committed in that jurisdiction.Â  
On November 22, 1999, after serving his sentence in North Carolina, Petitioner was transferred to South Carolina to complete his sentence for the armed robbery convictions.Â  Petitioner filed his PCR application on May 19, 2000.Â  The PCR judge dismissed the PCR application, finding it was filed after the one-year statutory filing period.Â  Petitioner appeals and requests this Court remand the case for a full evidentiary hearing.
ISSUE

Does the statute of limitations for PCR applications, S.C. CodeÂ  Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003), apply to an applicant who is incarcerated in another jurisdiction?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary dismissal of a PCR application without a hearing is appropriate only when (1) it is apparent on the face of the application that there is no need for a hearing to develop any facts and (2) the applicant is not entitled to relief.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-70(b) and (c) (2003).Â  When considering the Stateâ€™s motion for summary dismissal of an application, where no evidentiary hearing has been held, the circuit court must assume facts presented by an applicant are true and view those facts in the light most favorable to the applicant.Â  Similarly, when reviewing the propriety of a dismissal, this Court must view the facts in the same fashion.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-80 (2003) (PCR actions are governed by usual rules of civil procedure); Wilson v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 559 S.E.2d 581 (2002); Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 364, 527 S.E.2d 742, 747 (2000).
In a case raising a novel issue of law, the appellate court is free to decide the question of law with no particular deference to the trial court.Â  Osprey v. Cabana Ltd. Partn., 340 S.C. 367, 372, 532 S.E.2d 269, 272 (2000); Iâ€™On v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 411, 526 S.E.2d 716, 718 (2000).Â  The Court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651, 594 S.E.2d 462, 465 (2004); Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner argues he filed his PCR application within one year from the date he returned to South Carolina.Â  Petitioner contends this Court should extend the rationale set forth in Odom v. State, 337 S.C. 256, 523 S.E.2d 753 (1999), and rule Petitioner was denied his â€œone bite at the appleâ€ because his involuntary detention in North Carolina prevented him from timely filing his PCR application.Â  We disagree.
A PCR application ordinarily â€œmust be filed within one year after the entry of a judgment of conviction or within one year after the sending of the remittitur to the lower court from an appeal or the filing of the final decision upon an appeal, whichever is later.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003).Â  
We conclude incarceration in another state does not toll the running of the statute of limitations.Â Â  Petitioner had a full year to submit a post-conviction petition.Â  Ignorance of the statute of limitations is not an excuse for late filing, even when the Petitioner claims he did not learn of the statute because he was incarcerated in another state.Â  See e.g., Brown v. State, 928 S.W.2d 453, 456 (Tenn. Crim. App. 1996); Phillips v. State, 890 S.W.2d 37, 38 (Tenn. Crim. App. 1994).
Petitioner relies on this Courtâ€™s decisions in Carter v. State, 337 S.C. 17, 522 S.E.2d 342 (1999) and Wilson v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 559 S.E.2d 581 (2002) in arguing for equitable relief.Â  These cases are distinguishable from the present case.
In Carter, the defendant was incarcerated in federal prison.Â  The PCR judge dismissed the defendantâ€™s PCR application without prejudice allowing the defendant the right to apply for PCR when he was later incarcerated in a State facility.Â  This Court affirmed the PCR judgeâ€™s dismissal of the case without prejudice to the defendantâ€™s right to later file an application.Â  The present case is distinguishable.Â  In Carter, the State consented to the dismissal of the PCR application after the statute of limitations had run and agreed the defendant should be allowed to refile at a subsequent date.Â  Therefore, the State was estopped from asserting the statute of limitations.Â  Carter, 337 S.C. at 19, 522 S.E.2d at 342.
Petitioner contends this Courtâ€™s holding in Wilson supports Petitionerâ€™s argument for equitable relief.Â  We disagree.Â  In Wilson, the defendant instructed his attorney to appeal his conviction and the attorney failed to do so.Â  Wilson filed a PCR application alleging ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  The PCR judge dismissed the defendantâ€™s claim because it was untimely under the statute of limitations.Â  This Court reversed the PCR judge and remanded the case for an evidentiary hearing to determine if the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to direct appeal.Â  Wilson, 348 S.C. at 218, 559 S.E.2d at 583.Â  In the present case, Petitioner does not allege he instructed his attorney to appeal his conviction.
Petitioner also relies on this Courtâ€™s decision in Clayton v. State, 278 S.C. 655, 301 S.E.2d 133 (1983).Â  In Clayton, the Court concluded the State does not have the duty and authority to ensure an out-of-state prisonerâ€™s presence at a South Carolina PCR hearing.Â  However, the fact that the State is not required to transport federal inmates for State PCR proceedings, does not prevent an out-of-state inmate from filing a PCR application within the statute of limitations.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the decision of the PCR judge and conclude a prisonerâ€™s incarceration in another jurisdiction does not equitably toll the limitations period for post-conviction relief.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER AND PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Winns v. State
description: The Court reversed the PCR courtâ€™s ruling vacating respondent-petitionerâ€™s conviction, and held that the indictment was sufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction.
text:
BENCH MEMORANDUM


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Herman Winns, Respondent-Petitioner,
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner-Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Berkeley County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Daniel F. Pieper, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Opinion No. 25958
Submitted December 2, 2004 - Filed March 28, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Capers G. Barr, III, of Barr, Unger & McIntosh, of Charleston, for respondent-petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia, for petitioner-respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  The post-conviction relief (PCR) judge vacated respondent-petitioner Herman Winnsâ€™s conviction for murder, after finding that the indictment was defective because it failed to state the time and place of the victimâ€™s death.Â  The PCR judge also ruled that Winnsâ€™s claims regarding ineffective assistance of counsel lacked merit.Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari on the indictment issue and Winnsâ€™s petition for certiorari on the ineffective assistance of counsel issues.Â  After careful consideration, we dismiss Winnâ€™s petition for certiorari as improvidently granted on the ineffective assistance of counsel issues, and we reverse the PCRâ€™s judgeâ€™s ruling on the indictment
issue. 
Factual/Procedural Background
On a Friday afternoon, after having been laid off from his job earlier in the week, Winns went to St. Stephens, South Carolina, to visit some family and friends.Â  Once there, Winns decided to buy some crack cocaine.Â  A friend suggested that Winns visit John Arthur Mouzon, the victim, who was a known drug dealer and lived in Belangia Apartments.Â  Winns and Mouzon had never met before.Â  At approximately 1:30 p.m., Winns went to Mouzonâ€™s apartment and bought $50 worth of crack cocaine and smoked it in Mouzonâ€™s apartment. 
After Winns spent all of his money, he asked Mouzon for a ride to Winnsâ€™s auntâ€™s house.Â  Winnsâ€™s aunt gave him $20, which he used to buy more crack cocaine.Â  Although Winns went to a local convenience store at least four or five times to purchase beer, and visited other people in the area, he spent most of the afternoon and evening at Mouzonâ€™s apartment.Â  Winns eventually ran out of money again, and asked Mouzon if he would give Winns some crack cocaine anyway, and Mouzon did.
Winns testified that later that night, he and Mouzon were sitting on the couch when Mouzon put his hand on Winnsâ€™s thigh.Â  Because of this, Winns decided to leave.Â  But before leaving, Winns went into the bathroom, and when he came out, Winns found Mouzon lying on the bed, naked, with a sheet pulled up to his waist.Â  Winns testified that, instead of leaving right away, he walked toward the bed to get more crack cocaine.Â  When Winns was by the bed, Mouzon grabbed Winns by the groin, pulled him onto the bed, and told him that he needed to pay him back for the crack he had given him.Â  Winns reacted by hitting Mouzon on the head several times with an iron[1] until Mouzon released his grip. 
At approximately 3:40 a.m., Winns left the apartment with the iron in his hand, eventually throwing it into the bushes.Â  Later, at approximately 7:30 a.m., Mouzonâ€™s cousin came to the apartment and found Mouzon lying on the bed.Â  She said he was cold and did not have a pulse.Â  The police arrived later that morning and determined that Mouzon had been dead for a while.Â  That afternoon, Winns turned himself in and admitted that he struck Mouzon with the iron.
At trial, the central issue was whether Winns acted in self-defense or whether his actions constituted manslaughter or murder.Â  The jury found Winns guilty of murder and the judge sentenced Winns to life imprisonment.Â  Winns appealed and this Court affirmed his conviction.Â  State v. Winns, Mem. Op. No. 00-MO-078 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 26, 2000).Â  Winns applied for PCR.
After a hearing, the PCR judge found that the indictment was flawed because it did not state the time and place of the victimâ€™s death.Â  As a result, the judge vacated the conviction, finding that the trial court did not have subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The judge also ruled that Winnsâ€™s ineffective assistance of counsel claims lacked merit.
The State petitioned this Court for certiorari on the indictment issue, and Winns petitioned on the ineffective assistance of counsel issues.Â  This Court granted both petitions.Â  But after careful consideration, we dismiss certiorari as improvidently granted on the ineffective assistance of counsel issues, and address only the following issue, raised by the State:

Did the PCR court err in vacating Winnsâ€™s conviction on the basis that the indictment failed to state the time and place of the victimâ€™s death? 

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
This Court gives great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000).Â  On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any evidence of probative value to support them.Â  Id. at 109-110, 525 S.E.2d at 517.Â  
To establish a claim that counsel was ineffective, a PCR applicant must show that counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness, and but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability that the outcome of the trial would have been different. Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 688, 694 (1984); Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcomeâ€ of the trial.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694.
Indictment
The State argues that the PCR judge erred in ruling that the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the indictment failed to state the time and place of the victimâ€™s death.Â  We agree.
South Carolina statutory law provides the following:

Every indictment for murder shall be deemed and adjudged sufficient and good in law which, in addition to setting forth the time and place, together with a plain statement, divested of all useless phraseology, of the manner in which the death of the deceased was caused, charges that the defendant did feloniously, wilfully and of his malice aforethought kill and murder the deceased.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-30 (1985).
Moreover, this Court has held that an indictment for murder is sufficient â€œif the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer, and if an acquittal or a conviction thereon may be pleaded as a bar to any subsequent prosecution.â€ Joseph v. State, 351 S.C. 551, 561, 571 S.E.2d 280, 285 (2002) (citing State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 648, 552 S.E.2d 745, 751 (2001)).Â  In addition, the court must look at the indictment with a practical eye in view of the surrounding circumstances.Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1993).Â  Whether an indictment could be more certain or definite is irrelevant.Â  State v. Knuckles, 354 S.C. 626, 628, 583 S.E.2d 51, 51-52 (2003).
In the present case, the PCR judge ruled that the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the indictment did not allege the time and place of the victimâ€™s death.Â  Accordingly, the PCR judge vacated Winnsâ€™s conviction.Â  In support of this ruling, the PCR court cited State v. Rector, 158 S.C. 212, 155 S.E. 383 (1930).Â  In that case, the Court held that the use of the words â€œthen and thereâ€ sufficiently stated the time and place of death because those terms clearly referred back to the only date and place listed in the indictment.Â  Id. at 216, 155 S.E. at 387.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the case at hand, the indictment reads as follows:

That HERMAN WINNS did in Berkeley County on or about October 4, 1997 while at apartment #5 at Belangia Apartments in the town of St. Stephen, South Carolina, with malice aforethought, strike John Arthur Mouzon several times in the head with a metal object, said blows to the head being the proximate cause of the death of John Arthur Mouzon.Â  This action being in violation of Â§16-3-10, South Carolina Code of Law (1976), as amended.

We hold that the PCR court erred in finding the indictment defective.Â  Although the indictment did not state that Mouzon did â€œthen and thereâ€ die, the only logical reading of the indictment is that on October 4, 1997, Winns hit Mouzon in the head several times, at the Belangia Apartments, and Mouzon died either at the time he was attacked or soon thereafter.Â  The indictment provides the time of death (October 4, 1997) and the place of death (the Belangia Apartments, St. Stephens, South Carolina).Â  Had the victim been found in a different location or on a different date, the indictment, as written, may have been insufficient.Â  But because Mouzon was found dead in his bed, on the same day and in the same place where Winns struck him, and because the indictment explained that the blows to the head were the â€œproximate cause of death,â€ we find that the indictment states the offense of murder with sufficient certainty and particularity such that Winns knew what he was being called upon to answer.[2]Â  Accordingly, the indictment was not defective.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we REVERSE the PCR courtâ€™s ruling vacating Winnsâ€™s conviction, and hold that the indictment was sufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction. 
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In reviewing the sufficiency of an indictment, we look solely to the words used therein and not to the evidence adduced at trial.Â  Here, the post-conviction relief (PCR) judge, relying upon this Courtâ€™s long-established precedent, found the murder indictment invalid because it failed to sufficiently allege the time and place of the victimâ€™s death as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-30 (1985).Â  I agree, and would therefore affirm.
The â€œtime and place of deathâ€ requirement found in Â§ 17-19-30 merely codifies the common law.Â  State v. Rector, 158 S.C. 212, 155 S.E. 385 (1930).Â  Where the indictment references the place and date of the assault, and alleges that the victim died â€œthen and there,â€ this requirement has been satisfied.Â  Id.; see also State v. Platt, 154 S.C. 1, 151 S.E. 206 (1930); State v. Blakeney, 33 S.C. 111, 11 S.E. 637 (1890).Â  The present indictment alleges the time and place of the assault, but is silent on the time and place of the victimâ€™s death.Â  As the Court said in State v. Rector:

The crime of murder is a composite one.Â  It includes the assault committed upon a person . . . and the resulting death from that assault.Â  The State must prove not only the assault and the death occurring from it, but the time of the assault and the time of the death, as time is recognized in the law.Â  In addition, the state [sic] must prove the place of the assault and the place of death.Â  These necessary elements of the crime of murder must not only be proved, before a person accused may be lawfully convicted, but they must be alleged in the indictment returned against the accused by the grand jury.Â  The provisions of the Constitution, recognizing and following the principles of the common law, require the indictment to contain allegations to those effects.

The PCR judge correctly vacated respondent-petitionerâ€™s murder conviction, there being no valid indictment charging him with that offense.Â  In light of this, there is no need to address the allegations of ineffective assistance of counsel. 

[1] The iron was the type heated by a stove and used for ironing clothes. 
[2] We note that our decision in this case is consistent with the recently published opinion of State v. Gentry, Op. No. 25949 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 7, 2005), which explains that indictments are notice documents, not documents required to confer subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 11 (providing that circuit courts are â€œgeneral trial court[s] with original jurisdiction in civil and criminal cases, except those cases in which exclusive jurisdiction shall be given to inferior courts, and shall have such appellate jurisdiction as provided by lawâ€).Â
