title: Hurd v. Williamsburg County
description: In this case, the majority concludes the trial judge properly submitted the case to the jury because the passenger presented evidence that the shoulder of the road was not a reasonably safe place for the bus driver to allow the passenger to exit.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Jack Hurd, Respondent,
v.
Williamsburg County and Williamsburg County Transit Authority,
Petitioners.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF
CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25959
Heard January 4, 2005 - Filed March 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. and S. Elizabeth Brosnan, of Richardson, Plowden, Carpenter & Robinson, P.A., of Columbia, and Stephen Paul Bucher, of Bucher Firm, P.C., of North Charleston, for Petitioners.
Ladson Fishburne Howell, Jr., of Howell and Christmas, L.L.C., and Richard G. Wern, of The Wern Law Firm, P.A., both of North Charleston, and Ronnie Alan Sabb, of Law Offices of Ronnie A. Sabb, of Kingstree, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 353 S.C. 596, 579 S.E.2d 136 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On February 1, 1996, Respondent (Hurd) was struck by an automobile after he exited a bus owned and operated by Petitioners Williamsburg County and the Williamsburg County Transit Authority (collectively referred to as the â€œTransit Authorityâ€).Â Â  
At approximately 6:00 AM on February 1, 1996, Hurd boarded the bus in route to Myrtle Beach.Â  The busâ€™ interim destination was a transfer station, known as a â€œPark and Ride,â€ where passengers could purchase tokens, board buses, and transfer to other locations.Â  Before arriving at the Park and Ride, the bus stopped on the shoulder of the road across a two-lane highway from Mingoâ€™s store, a gas station and restaurant.Â  Hurd testified he was â€œhalf awake and half asleepâ€ when the bus stopped.Â  The stopping of the bus roused Hurd, whereupon he asked the bus driver where the disembarking passengers were going.Â  The driver informed Hurd the passengers were going for breakfast at Mingoâ€™s.Â  Hurd stated he exited and walked to the rear of the bus, to join the other passengers, without any instructions from the driver. 
Hurd testified the bus began to pull off the shoulder and into the highway as Hurd approached the highway.Â  The bus was moving when Hurd stepped into the highway.Â  Because Hurd was standing at the rear of the bus where the engine is located, he was not able to hear the oncoming car.Â  Hurd testified he was unable to see the car because of the angle of the moving bus and stepped into the highway.Â  The driver of the car stated he never saw Hurd prior to impact.Â  
Respondent filed suit against Petitioners and the jury returned a verdict finding Hurd 42 percent at fault and the Transit Authority 58 percent at fault.Â  The jury awarded Hurd $675,000 in damages.Â  The trial court reduced the award of damages to $250,000 pursuant to the South Carolina Tort Claims Act (SCTCA).Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed the juryâ€™s verdict finding the trial court did not err in denying Transit Authority a directed verdict.Â  Transit Authority appeals.
ISSUES

  
    
    
      
        I.    
         Did the Court of Appeals change the common law standard of negligence in determining the trial judge properly submitted the case to the jury?
      
      
        II.  
         Did the Court of Appeals err in concluding Hurd presented evidence allowing the inference that the Transit Authorityâ€™s actions were the proximate cause of the accident?
      
      
        III. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err in concluding Hurd presented evidence Transit Authorityâ€™s negligence exceeded Hurdâ€™s negligence?
      
    
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
When reviewing a ruling on a motion for directed verdict, we must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  F & D Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Powder Coaters, Inc., 350 S.C. 454, 567 S.E.2d 842 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, the trial judge must submit the case to the jury.Â  Quesinberry v. Rouppasong, 331 S.C. 589, 503 S.E.2d 717 (1998).Â  We will reverse the trial court if there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s decision to submit the case to the jury.Â  Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999).Â  
I.
Transit Authority argues the Court of Appeals erred in changing the common law standard of negligence from reasonable care to â€œbest choice careâ€ in concluding Transit Authority was not entitled to a directed verdict.Â  Specifically, Transit Authority contends Hurd was let off in a position of reasonable safety and Hurd failed to present evidence establishing Transit Authority breached any duty of safety owed to Hurd.Â  We disagree.Â  
During the trial, Robert Roberts, an expert in the area of traffic engineering and traffic and pedestrian safety, testified it was unreasonable for the bus driver to discharge the passengers on the shoulder of Highway 41.Â  Roberts also testified that the Park and Ride was a safety device, among other things.Â  Booker T. Pressley, a former director of the Transit Authority, testified that chief among the concerns that led to the Countyâ€™s construction of the Park and Ride was high traffic congestion.Â  Pressley stated Transit Authorityâ€™s policy is to only let passengers off at the Park and Ride on Highway 41 because of the congestion.Â  See Caldwell v. K-Mart Corp., 306 S.C. 27, 31-32, 410 S.E.2d 21, 24 (Ct. App. 1991) (when defendant adopts internal policies or self-imposed rules and thereafter violates those policies or rules, jury may consider such violations as evidence of negligence if they proximately caused a plaintiffâ€™s damages).Â  Because more than one inference could be drawn from this evidence, we conclude the Court of Appeals correctly found the trial judge did not err in denying Transit Authorityâ€™s motion for directed verdict.[1]
The Court of Appeals did not heighten the standard of care in concluding Hurd presented evidence supporting his allegation that he was not discharged in a reasonably safe place.Â  Instead, the Court of Appeals relied on this Courtâ€™s decision in Flynn v. Carolina Scenic Stages, 237 S.C. 340, 117 S.E.2d 364 (1960).Â  In Flynn, this Court acknowledged that the relation of passenger and a common carrier ordinarily ends when the passenger steps from a bus into a reasonably safe place on a public highway.Â  However, a carrier is not then wholly discharged of any duty whatsoever to such passenger.Â  It still owes the duty of exercising ordinary care to see that after alighting safely the passenger is not in a position or situation as to be imperiled by the starting up of the bus.Â  Flynn, 237 S.C. at 345, 117 S.E.2d 364 at 367.Â  We conclude the trial judge properly submitted the case to the jury because Hurd presented evidence based on the facts of this case that the shoulder of the highway was not a reasonably safe place to allow Hurd to exit the bus.
II.
Transit Authority argues the Court of Appeals erred in concluding Hurd presented evidence that Transit Authorityâ€™s actions were the proximate cause of Hurdâ€™s injuries.Â  Transit Authority contends the side of the road where the bus discharged passengers departing for Mingoâ€™s was a place of reasonable safety as a matter of law.Â  We disagree.Â  
In a negligence action the plaintiff must prove proximate cause.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 426 S.E.2d 802 (1993).Â  â€œOrdinarily, the question of proximate cause is one of fact for the jury and the trial judgeâ€™s sole function regarding the issue is to inquire whether particular conclusions are the only reasonable inferences that can be drawn from the evidence.â€Â  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 349, 499 S.E.2d 488, 497 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Proximate cause requires proof of both causation in fact and legal cause.Â  Oliver v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Hwys. & Pub. Transp., 309 S.C. 313, 422 S.E.2d 128 (1992).Â  Causation in fact is proved by establishing the plaintiffâ€™s injury would not have occurred â€œbut forâ€ the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Oliver, 309 S.C. at 316, 422 S.E.2d at 130.Â  Legal cause is proved by establishing foreseeability.Â  Id.Â  An injury is foreseeable if it is the natural and probable consequence of a breach of duty.Â  Trivelas v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
We conclude Hurd presented evidence of both factual and legal causation.Â  Hurd presented evidence that â€œbut forâ€ the bus pulling out concurrently with Hurd attempting to cross the road, Hurd would not have been struck by the oncoming car.Â  Hurd also presented evidence that the vehicle-pedestrian accident was foreseeable.Â  Pressleyâ€™s testimony is evidence suggesting (1) the Transit Authority knew that the location of the accident was dangerous to pedestrians; (2) the County constructed the Park and Ride to minimize known dangers at this intersection; (3) the Transit Authority implemented a policy that all drivers were to use the Park and Ride rather than the shoulder of the Highway; (4) the Transit Authority violated its own safety policy by discharging Hurd and the other passengers on the side of the highway; (5) Transit Authority issued the bus driver a warning for violating the safety policy on the date of the accident; and (6) the starting of the bus prevented Hurd from hearing or seeing traffic on the highway.Â  
Based on the foregoing evidence, the Court of Appeals was correct in affirming the trial judgeâ€™s decision to allow the question of proximate cause to go to the jury.Â  Hurd does not contend the Transit Authorityâ€™s negligence was the sole cause of his injuries.Â  Nevertheless, Hurd presented evidence at trial that the Transit Authorityâ€™s negligence contributed to the accident.Â  Therefore, the case was properly submitted to the jury.
III.
Transit Authority argues the Court of Appeals erred in concluding Hurd presented evidence that Transit Authorityâ€™s negligence exceeded Hurdâ€™s own negligence.Â  We disagree.
A plaintiff may only recover damages if his own negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 529 S.E.2d 710 (2000).Â  The determination of respective degrees of negligence attributable to the plaintiff and the defendant presents a question of fact for the jury, at least where conflicting inferences may be drawn.Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife and Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 491 S.E.2d 571 (1997).Â  In a comparative negligence case, the trial court should grant a motion for directed verdict if the sole reasonable inference from the evidence is that the non-moving partyâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.Â  Bloom, 339 S.C. at 422, 529 S.E.2d at 713.
We conclude the Court of Appeals correctly determined Hurd presented evidence allowing the jury to draw a reasonable inference that Transit Authorityâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.Â  A directed verdict for Transit Authority would have been inappropriate because Hurd presented evidence that Transit Authority violated its own safety policy by discharging passengers on the shoulder of the road.Â  This evidence is reinforced by Transit Authorityâ€™s own admission that the driver of the bus was given a warning in connection with the incident.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because there is evidence that would allow a jury to conclude Transit Authority was negligent in discharging Hurd on the shoulder of the road, we affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.
 MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., and PLEICONES, J., dissenting in separate opinions.


Chief Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, the Transit Authority exercised reasonable care in dropping off its passenger.Â  Therefore, I would reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision holding that the Transit Authority breached its duty of care to Hurd.
I disagree with the majority because, in my opinion, the majority holds the Transit Authority to a higher duty of care than what is required of common carriers.Â  A common carrier is required to allow a passenger to exit the bus in a reasonably safe place.Â  Flynn v. Carolina Scenic Stages, 237 S.C. 340, 345, 117 S.E.2d 364, 366-367 (1960).Â  Further, the relationship between passenger and carrier ordinarily ends when the passenger steps from a bus into a reasonably safe place on a public highway.Â  Id.Â  Other courts have been reluctant to hold common carriers liable for injuries suffered after the passenger safely exits.Â  See e.g. Burton v. Des Moines Metro. Transit Auth., 530 N.W.2d 696, 699 (Iowa 1995) (holding that the duty of a common carrier ends when the passenger safely exits and carriers are not liable for injuries caused by the passengers decision to step into traffic).Â  In Burton, the Iowa Supreme Court explained the rationale for holding that a carrierâ€™s duty ends once a passenger exits the bus:

[A]fter alighting, the passengerâ€™s individual choice directs where he or she will walk, the passenger is in a better position to guard against the dangers of moving vehicles and common sense, logic, and public policy simply do not support extending a duty of care of the public carrier to insure that once the passenger has safely departed, the streets will be free from defect.Â  

Id. (citing Connolly v. Rogers, 599 N.Y.S.2d 731, 732 (N.Y. App. Div. 1993) (quoting Blye v. Mahattan, 511 N.Y.S.2d 612, 615, affâ€™d, 528 N.E.2d 1225 (N.Y. 1988)) (emphasis added).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the present case, the Transit Authority dropped Hurd off on the shoulder of the road, out of harmâ€™s way.Â  The gravel shoulder was a defined turn out at least 200 feet long and at least twice as wide as the bus.Â  Hurd then chose to cross the street, taking himself out of a safe place and inserting himself into a dangerous place, that is, the middle of the road.Â  Hurd claims that the Transit Authority bus blocked vision when it pulled off, but the fact is, Hurd was in a safe place until he decided to cross the street before he could see clearly.[2]Â  In essence, he walked right out in front of a car with its lights on.Â  In my opinion, the Transit Authority fulfilled the duty owed to Hurd by allowing Hurd to exit in a reasonably safe place - the shoulder of the highway.Â  Because I believe the majorityâ€™s holding heightens the duty of care owed by common carriers to a level beyond reasonable care, I would reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision and hold that the Transit Authority was entitled to a directed verdict.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the dissent that the Transit Authority was entitled to a directed verdict, as there was no evidence that the shoulder of the road was an unreasonable place to let Hurd exit the bus.

[1] The logic of the dissent is inescapable, however, our duty is
guided by a standard requiring submission to the fact-finder of contested issues of fact.Â  Whether the shoulder of the road was a reasonably safe place for the discharge of passengers was a contested issue the jury resolved against Transit Authority. 
[2]Â  It is undisputed that the shoulder of the road was a reasonably safe place.Â  In fact, on cross-examination of Hurdâ€™s expert, the following exchange took place:Â  

  
    
    
      
        Q.
         [W]hen the bus driver discharged Mr. Hurd along the roadside in the shoulder that at the moment that he got out of the bus and was there along the shoulder he was in a place where it was safe for him to beâ€¦
      
      
        A.
         As long as he stood there.Â  Yes.Â  Reasonably safe, sir.Â Â Â 
      
    
    
  

Instead the issue on appeal has been framed to determine whether the existence of a â€œsaferâ€ drop off area, such as a Park and Ride, makes the place the passenger actually exited unsafe.Â  This is simply not the appropriate standard that common carriers are charged to uphold.Â  The majority heightens the duty a common carrier owes to its passengers to a â€œbest choiceâ€ standard, which is inconsistent with the current standard of care for common carriers.Â  I fear that heightening the standard of care for a common carrier could create a nightmare scenario for rural area transit authorities.Â  For example, under the rationale of the majority, a carrier could be found negligent for dropping off a passenger in a reasonably safe place because the carrier did not choose the best place to drop off the passenger, which might be two blocks down the street.

title: In the Matter of the Estate of Mary Frances Pallister
description: The circuit court affirmed the decision of a probate court jury, which found that Mary Frances Pallister had not revoked her will prior to her death, although the original will was lost or missing.  The Supreme Court affirmed, holding (1) the record contains evidence supporting the jury's verdict that Respondent proved, by clear and convincing evidence, that the will had been lost or destroyed by a third party without the decedent's knowledge or consent; and (2) the probate court properly instructed the jury on the applicable law.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of the Estate of Mary Frances Pallister
Ann Garman Diem Patton, as personal representative of the Estate of Ruth Eleanor Diem,
Respondent,
v.
James E. Reames, Stephen L. Reames, Marsha R.
Bozard, and David S. Reames, as personal representative of the Estate of F.S.
Reames, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25960
Heard February 15, 2005 - Filed March 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John R. Chase, of Haynsworth Sinker Boyd, P.A., of Florence, and B. Eric Shytle, and Sarah P. Spruill, both of Haynsworth Sinkler Boyd, P.A., of Columbia, for Appellants.
Kenneth B. Wingate and Paul D. Kent, of Sweeny, Wingate and Barrow, P.A., of Columbia, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  

 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This is a lost or missing will case.Â  A probate court jury found that Ann Patton, personal representative of the Estate of Ruth Eleanor Diem, proved by clear and convincing evidence Mary Frances Pallister (Testatrix) did not destroy her original last will and testament with an intent to revoke it.[1]Â  The circuit court affirmed the verdict and Appellants, the nephews and niece of Testatrix, appeal.Â  We certified this case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and now affirm.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Testatrix died April 7, 2001, at the age of 89, leaving an estate with an estimated, after-tax value of $1.4 million.Â  Testatrixâ€™s husband predeceased her and she left no children. 
The parties agreed Testatrix was competent to execute the last will and testament dated October 22, 1999, the will in issue, but litigated the question whether the will was revoked by Testatrix because the original document could not be found after Testatrixâ€™s death.Â  Ruth Eleanor Diem (Diem), the primary beneficiary to the will, was the sister of Testatrixâ€™s husband.Â  Patton, a contingent beneficiary in the will, is Diemâ€™s daughter.Â  James Reames (James) and the other Appellants are the children of Testatrixâ€™s two brothers.Â  
James is a contingent beneficiary in the will, but will not take under it because Diem survived Testatrix.Â  James and the other Appellants would inherit Testatrixâ€™s estate if the will is deemed destroyed with an intent to revoke, such that intestacy laws apply.
Testatrix executed two wills while living in New Mexico.Â  The primary and contingent beneficiaries named in Testatrixâ€™s 1983 will were her husband, Diem, and Patton.Â  The 1983 will named these same persons as personal representatives in the same order of priority.
The primary and contingent beneficiaries named in Testatrixâ€™s 1997 will, prepared after her husbandâ€™s death, were Diem, Patton, and Testatrixâ€™s sister-in-law, Lola Reames, wife of Testatrixâ€™s brother and mother of James.Â  The 1997 will named these same persons as personal representatives in the same order of priority. 
Diem and Patton lived in California, while Testatrix lived in New Mexico during the last two decades of her life.Â  Testatrix and Diem were close friends for fifty-five years, staying in touch through visits, joint vacations, telephone calls, cards, and letters.Â  Diem was Testatrixâ€™s matron of honor at her 1946 wedding.Â  Patton and Testatrix maintained a similar, close relationship.
Testatrix, who grew up in Bishopville, S.C., moved from New Mexico to South Carolina in 1998.Â  The will in issue was prepared by a South Carolina attorney and executed on October 22, 1999.[2]Â  In this will, Testatrix named as her primary and contingent beneficiaries Diem, Patton, and James, a Florence resident.Â  The 1999 will named these same persons as personal representatives in the same order of priority.Â  Testatrix told her accountant in South Carolina she planned to leave her estate to Diem and Patton, i.e., her husbandâ€™s side of the family, to honor the memory of her husband and his efforts.Â  He was the primary breadwinner and his earnings and investment acumen resulted in an estate which afforded Testatrix a comfortable lifestyle. 
After moving to South Carolina, Testatrix placed Diem and Patton as joint-signatories on her bank accounts and granted them right of access to her safe deposit box.Â  About a month after executing the 1999 will, Testatrix signed a durable power of attorney naming Diem as her agent, with Patton as alternate agent, in financial and other matters.Â  On the date she executed the 1999 will, Testatrix signed a health care power of attorney naming James as her agent for health care decisions if she were to become mentally incompetent.
Testatrix, by all accounts, was a â€œdelightful,â€ â€œorganizedâ€ woman who knew her own mind and did not hesitate to express her wishes and opinions.Â  The attorney who prepared the 1999 will testified she discussed various types of trusts with Testatrix, but Testatrix desired only a simple will.Â  The attorney delivered the original will to Testatrix and encouraged her to place it in a safe deposit box. 
Testatrixâ€™s tax accountant testified Testatrix was an organized, â€œby the booksâ€ person.Â  Administrators at the Methodist Manor, where Testatrix lived, described her, although she had some physical frailties, as â€œorganized,â€ â€œon the ball,â€ â€œvery sharp mentally,â€ and an â€œindependent, private person.â€Â  Diem, Patton, and James offered similar testimony.Â  Such testimony referred to witnessesâ€™ general knowledge of Testatrix during the years they knew her and was not necessarily focused on the last weeks of her
life.
Testatrix was generous to close relatives.Â  From 1996 to 1999, Testatrix gave, in cash or assets such as stocks and bonds, $183,000 to Patton, $30,000 to Diem, and $104,000 to James.Â  In addition, Testatrix made a business loan of $100,000 to James in 2000, although James apparently considered it a gift, not a loan. 
While living at the Methodist Manor in Florence, Testatrix gradually developed a close relationship with James and his family.Â  James visited and helped Testatrix at her home at least once or twice a week.Â  Testatrix sometimes had dinner at Jamesâ€™ home.Â  James testified he visited Testatrix at her home or in the hospital every day during the last several weeks of her life as her health worsened, at times spending most or all of the day with her.Â  A nurse assistant, who sat with Testatrix at the hospital on the evening of her death and who did not know the family, testified Testatrix repeatedly asked for James during the final hours of her life.Â  
James testified he knew where Testatrix kept financial records at her home, including her bank and brokerage accounts, and he sometimes filed financial documents for her.Â  Testatrix kept extensive financial records from years past.Â  James helped Testatrix sort her mail, but did not discard anything without her permission.Â  At trial James initially denied helping Testatrix with her financial or business matters in the final months of her life.Â  When confronted with his conflicting deposition testimony, James testified he wrote checks for Testatrix and sometimes even signed her name.Â  He carried a bag, containing Testatrixâ€™s checkbooks and investment records, for Testatrix while taking her to and from the hospital in the last weeks of her life.
James testified he had a key to Testatrixâ€™s Methodist Manor apartment â€œfrom day one.â€Â  He also had the keys to her car, which he testified she gave him several months before her death.Â  The record shows, however, the title never had been transferred by Testatrixâ€™s signature.Â  James, a car salesman for thirty-two years, testified that although he was â€œin the used car business . . . I do not do title work.â€
He further testified Testatrix gave him a copy of the 1999 will some time following its execution.Â  He saw the will a second time two to three months before Testatrixâ€™s death in January or February 2001, lying on a table in her apartment.Â  On that occasion, he picked it up when it fell on the floor with some books and replaced it on the table.Â  He testified he did not know what happened to the original 1999 will and denied discarding or destroying it.Â  
Testatrix was hospitalized with congestive heart failure and related health problems for eight days in March 2001 and from April 5 until her death on April 7, 2001.Â  In the last month of her life, Testatrix and part of her belongings were moved from her independent living unit to an assisted living unit at the Methodist Manor.
On April 4, 2001, James asked a bank officer to contact Testatrix at her apartment.Â  The bank officer testified she spoke with Testatrix by telephone and, at Testatrixâ€™s direction, prepared forms to add James to Testatrixâ€™s checking and money market accounts on which Diem and Patton already were listed as joint signatories.Â  The bank officer also prepared a form allowing James to enter Testatrixâ€™s safe deposit box. 
James obtained an account transfer form from Testatrixâ€™s brokerage firm on April 4.Â  James asked a brokerage representative to accompany him to the Methodist Manor to assist his aunt in completing the form, but the representative was unable to leave the office.
James took the bank and brokerage forms to Testatrixâ€™s apartment.Â  He testified Testatrix, who was using an oxygen tank, signed the forms in the presence of a notary public, who was a Methodist Manor employee; an unidentified â€œsitterâ€ who was staying with Testatrix that afternoon; and an unidentified, older woman who was a Manor resident and friend of Testatrixâ€™s.Â  Signing the forms consumed about half an hour.Â  The notary public later testified that only he, Testatrix, and James were in the apartment when the forms were signed during a five-minute period.
James returned to the bank and brokerage firm the same afternoon.Â  James transferred $80,000 from Testatrixâ€™s joint bank accounts to his individual account.Â  He transferred Testatrixâ€™s brokerage account, worth about $633,000, to his individual brokerage account.[3]  
On the morning of April 5, 2001, James entered Testatrixâ€™s safe deposit box for the first time.Â  He testified he did so out of â€œcuriosityâ€ and to search for the health care power of attorney form which had been requested by her doctor in order to admit Testatrix to the hospital.Â  James and his wife testified they could not find the form Testatrix had given James because many of their belongings were in storage while they built a new home.Â  James testified he again entered Testatrixâ€™s safe deposit box after her death on April 9, 2001, in the presence of a bank officer, to retrieve vehicle-related documents. 
Patton testified she and Diem first learned on April 10, 2001, about Jamesâ€™ transfer of assets to himself and his entries into Testatrixâ€™s safe deposit box.Â  Patton testified she and Diem, following Testatrixâ€™s death, could not find the original 1999 will in Testatrixâ€™s safe deposit box or among her belongings or other financial documents.Â  When they finally spoke to James by telephone after several attempts to reach him since arriving, he told them he had never seen Testatrixâ€™s will.Â  Patton and Diem visited Testatrixâ€™s apartment and found it in an uncharacteristically messy and unkempt state.
Testatrix had kept her previous wills in a safe deposit box.Â  The record is unclear whether Testatrix ever entered her safe deposit box after executing her last will on October 22, 1999.Â  The last date signed by Testatrix on the record of entry form was partially scratched out or written over.Â  A bank officer testified the ambiguous number may be an â€œ8â€ or a â€œ9â€ and appears to show Testatrix last entered the box on â€œ9-13-99,â€ although the date is uncertain. 
Patton testified she and Diem found an empty envelope marked â€œLast Will and Testamentâ€ when they entered Testatrixâ€™s safe deposit box on April 10, 2001.Â  The attorney who prepared Testatrixâ€™s 1999 will, however, testified the envelope was not similar to ones she used in such matters.Â  
James testified he was â€œconcernedâ€ when he first saw the 1999 will and â€œdidnâ€™t understand why it was the way it was when [Testatrix] had charged me with certain other responsibilities.â€Â  The attorney who prepared the will testified James expressed his anger about the will provisions to her in a telephone call shortly after the will had been prepared.Â  James said he was upset the entire estate was left to Diem or Patton, while he was burdened with helping Testatrix with health care and other matters without getting anything from the estate.Â  The attorney testified James accused her, wrongfully, of advising Testatrix to draft such a will.Â  Jamesâ€™ brother, Stephen Reames, testified at his deposition James told him - after he had transferred Testatrixâ€™s assets to himself - James had â€œgot his inheritance from [Testatrix].â€Â  Stephen testified at trial he could not recall whether James used the word â€œgiftâ€ or â€œinheritanceâ€ in describing the transferred assets. 
ISSUES

I.Â  Did the circuit court err in affirming the juryâ€™s verdict because Patton failed to present clear and convincing evidence rebutting the presumption Testatrix had destroyed her original will, which could not be found after her death, with an intent to revoke it? 
II.Â  Did the circuit court err in affirming the probate courtâ€™s refusal to instruct the jury on the principle that a person is never presumed to commit a crime?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to contest a will is an action at law.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 235 S.C. 542, 546, 112 S.E.2d 647, 649 (1960); Golini v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 333, 338, 482 S.E.2d 784, 787 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  If the proceeding in the probate court is in the nature of an action at law, the circuit court and the appellate court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence to support them.Â  Matter of Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993); Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976); In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 262, 495 S.E.2d 454, 460 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Under the Probate Code, a circuit court hearing an appeal from the probate court must apply the same rules of law as an appellate court would apply on appeal.Â  Matter ofÂ  Howard, 315 S.C. at 360-61, 434 S.E.2d at 256-57; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308 (Supp. 2004).
An appellate court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury instructions unless the trial court abused its discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.Â  Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 538, 354 S.E.2d 565, 566 (1987).
LAW AND ANALYSIS
I.Â  EVIDENCE SUPPORTING JURYâ€™S VERDICT
Appellants contend the probate and circuit courts erred in denying their directed verdict and post-trial motions for a judgment in their favor as a matter of law.Â  Appellants argue Patton failed to present clear and convincing evidence rebutting the presumption Testatrix had destroyed her will with an intent to revoke it because the original document could not be found after her death.Â  Appellants argue â€œthere is not a scintilla of evidence of a cause, other than revocation, for the Willâ€™s disappearance.â€Â  We disagree.
A will is an expression of a testatorâ€™s intent to dispose of the testatorâ€™s property after death.Â  A will may be freely modified or revoked by a mentally competent testator, acting of the testatorâ€™s own volition, until the testatorâ€™s death.Â  Lowe v. Fickling, 207 S.C. 442, 447, 36 S.E.2d 293, 294 (1945); S.C. Code Ann. 62-2-506 (1987) (revocation of will by writing or act).Â  
â€œWhen a testator takes possession of his [original] will and the same cannot be found after his death, the law presumes the testator destroyed it animo revocandi, i.e., with an intent to revoke it.Â  This is merely a presumption of fact and may be rebutted by the evidence the will existed at the time of his death, was lost subsequent thereto, or had been destroyed by another without authority to do so.Â  The same presumption arises where it is shown the testator, while not having the will in his actual possession, had ready access to it.â€Â  Lowe, 207 S.C. atÂ  447, 36 S.E.2d at 294-95; Bauskett v. Keitt, 22 S.C. 187, 191 (1885); Golini v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 333, 340, 482 S.E.2d 784, 787-88 (Ct. App. 1997); In re Estate of Mason, 289 S.C. 273, 277, 346 S.E.2d 28, 31 (Ct. App. 1986). 
Consequently, the person attempting to rebut the presumption and submit a copy of the lost or missing will to the probate court for administration must present clear and convincing evidence (1) the original will existed at the time of the testatorâ€™s death and (2) the original will was lost after his death or destroyed by a third party without the testatorâ€™s knowledge or consent.Â  Lowe, 207 S.C. at 447,Â  36 S.E.2d at 294-95; Golini, 326 S.C. at 340, 482 S.E.2d at 788; Estate of Mason, 289 S.C. at 277, 346 S.E.2d at 31.
The person contesting the validity of a will usually bears the burdens of proof and persuasion.Â  Golini, 326 S.C. at 340, 482 S.E.2d at 787; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-407 (Supp. 2004).Â  However, these burdens are reversed in cases of lost or missing wills.Â  The person asserting that an original will was, in fact, valid but mistakenly lost or destroyed by another, bears the burden of presenting clear and convincing evidence to rebut the presumption the testator destroyed the will with an intent to revoke it.Â  Lowe, 207 S.C. at 451, 36 S.E.2d at 296; Golini, 326 S.C. at 340, 482 S.E.2d at 788. 
The mere fact a person who would benefit from destruction of a will possessed it or had access to it, standing alone, is not sufficient to rebut the presumption the testator himself revoked the will by destroying it.Â  Lowe, 207 S.C. at 448, 36 S.E.2d at 295.Â  However, â€œ[p]roof that a testator, whose will cannot be found after death, entertained a kindly or loving feeling toward the beneficiaries under the Will carries weight and tends toward the conclusion of nonrevocation of the Will by the testator.â€Â  Golini, 326 S.C. at 342, 428 S.E.2d at 788-89.
We conclude Patton presented clear and convincing evidence from which a jury could determine the original 1999 will existed at the time of Testatrixâ€™s death, and it was either lost after her death or destroyed by a third party without her knowledge or consent.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the juryâ€™s verdict in favor of Patton. 
It is undisputed the 1999 will was valid upon execution.Â  The attorney testified she delivered the original will to Testatrix and James testified he saw it in her apartment two to three months before her death.Â  The primary and first contingent beneficiaries of the will were the same persons Testatrix had named in her wills since 1983 - Diem and Patton.Â  The record contains no evidence Testatrix expressed any desire to change or revoke her will in order not to pass assets to Diem and Patton; nor is there any evidence Testatrix grew unhappy or displeased with them in any way.Â  The record contains clear and convincing evidence upon which the jury may have relied in determining the original will existed at Testatrixâ€™s death.
Testatrix previously had kept her wills in a safe deposit box.Â  She may have placed the 1999 will in her box, although it is unclear due to the ambiguous date on the bankâ€™s record of entry form.Â  Regardless, Testatrix usually was an organized, â€œby the booksâ€ person who regularly maintained files containing current and past financial and investment documents.Â  Some of those documents were transported in a bag to and from the hospital on several occasions in the month preceding her death.Â  Some of her belongings were moved from an independent living unit to an assisted living unit at the Methodist Manor in the last weeks of her life.Â  Diem and Patton found Testatrixâ€™s apartment in an unusually disorganized and unkempt state after her death. 
In addition, Testatrix regularly had consulted professionals - lawyers, accountants, and stock brokers - throughout her life when making important decisions and preparing significant documents.Â  The jury may have reasoned that if Testatrix had wanted to revoke her 1999 will, it is not likely she would have torn it up or discarded it.Â  Instead, it is far more likely she would have consulted the lawyer who had drafted the will to make other arrangements.Â  The record contains clear and convincing evidence upon which the jury may have relied in determining the original 1999 will was misplaced or lost during Testatrixâ€™s final illness and frequent moves.
Moreover, James knew about the will and admitted he was displeased with its terms.Â  He telephoned Testatrixâ€™s attorney to complain about it and accused her of convincing Testatrix to leave everything to Diem and Patton.Â  He had unfettered access to Testatrixâ€™s apartment, knew where she kept financial and investment records, and by his own testimony spent days on end there as Testatrixâ€™s health worsened.Â  He had access to Testatrixâ€™s apartment for eleven days while she was hospitalized shortly before her death.
The mere fact James, who would benefit financially were the will revoked, had access to Testatrixâ€™s missing will is not, standing alone, sufficient to rebut the presumption Testatrix herself revoked it by destroying it.Â  However, in addition to the evidence of Testatrixâ€™s practice of keeping careful records and consulting professionals, the record reveals more than motive to destroy the will and opportunity to do so by a third party.
James acted decisively to ensure he received, using the word ascribed to him by his brother, his â€œinheritanceâ€ from Testatrix.Â  James transferred about $713,000 in assets from Decedent to himself on the day she re-entered the hospital - three days before her death - after obtaining her signature on necessary bank and brokerage forms. 
James testified several people were in the room during a half-hour signature session.Â  The notary public testified only he, James, and Testatrix were present during a five-minute period.Â  When questioned by Diem and Patton about the transfers and the location of Testatrixâ€™s original 1999 will after Testatrixâ€™s death, James told them he had never seen the will.Â  The record contains clear and convincing evidence upon which the jury may have relied in determining a third party destroyed the will without Testatrixâ€™s consent or knowledge.
II.Â  JURY INSTRUCTION
Appellants contend the probate court erred in refusing to give the following instruction to the jury:Â  â€œThe law does not presume that a will has been destroyed by another person without the knowledge or consent of the maker, for this would be a crime under the laws of South Carolina and a crime is never presumed.â€Â  Appellants argue the charge, drawn from Lowe, 207 S.C. atÂ  447, 36 S.E.2d at 295, was necessary to ensure the jury understood its verdict could not be based on speculation the will was destroyed by a third person.Â  We disagree.
The probate court, accepting Testatrixâ€™s arguments against the charge, rejected it because use of the term â€œcrimeâ€ was inflammatory and potentially placed too much weight on one method of rebutting the presumption a missing will was destroyed by the Testatrix with an intent to revoke it. 
A trial court must charge the current and correct law.Â  McCourt by McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 603, 606 (1995).Â  The law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence at trial.Â  State v. Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 262, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993).Â  In reviewing jury charges for error, appellate courts must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 575 (1999).Â  A jury charge is correct if, when read as a whole, it contains the correct definitions and adequately covers the law.Â  Id. at 495-96, 514 S.E.2d at 574; In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 94, 551 S.E.2d 235, 239 (2001).Â  It is not error for the trial judge to refuse a specific request to charge when the substance of the request is included in the general instructions.Â  Varnadore v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 289 S.C. 155, 160, 345 S.E.2d 711, 715 (1986).
We conclude the probate court judge properly instructed the jury on the law governing lost wills, the rebuttable presumption a testator destroyed his will with an intent to revoke if it cannot be found after his death, and Pattonâ€™s burden to rebut the presumption by clear and convincing evidence.Â Â  When read as a whole, the charge correctly defined and adequately covered the law.Â  Moreover, Appellantsâ€™ specific request to charge was included in the general instructions.Â  The probate court judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing the requested charge. 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the decision of the circuit court and thereby affirm the verdict of the probate court jury.Â  Patton may present a copy of Testatrixâ€™s 1999 will to the probate court for administration despite the loss of the original will.Â  
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, A.C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice L. Casey Manning, concur.

[1]Â  The jury rendered a verdict in favor of Ruth Eleanor Diem, Pattonâ€™s mother, who originally petitioned the probate court to accept the will and appoint her as Testatrixâ€™s personal representative.Â  Diem testified at trial.Â  After Diem died, Patton was substituted in her place as personal representative of Diemâ€™s estate.
[2]Â  The 1999 will contained the usual language revoking all prior wills and codicils.Â  The parties agree the 1999 will was valid upon execution.Â  If Testatrix subsequently revoked the 1999 will, that revocation would not revive a prior will absent clear, cogent, and convincing evidence Testatrix intended to revive the prior will.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-508 (1987).Â  The record contains no such revival evidence, therefore, Testatrixâ€™s estate would be distributed under intestacy laws if the 1999 will was revoked.
[3]Â  The parties tried only the issue of whether the 1999 will had been lost by mistake or destroyed with an intention to revoke it.Â  The jury heard evidence, but did not decide the validity, of Jamesâ€™ transfers of Testatrixâ€™s assets to himself.Â
